151402249.review:
I consider myself a calm and patient person. I have never opened the task manager and forcibly closed a game out of pure spite and annoyance until today.
There's a lot to like about this game: the graphics, the sound design, the satisfying gameplay loop. There's also a lot to dislike, most of which comes down to the RNG. I know this isn't a new complaint about DD by any means, but I really thought it wouldn't bother me, since I've played a lot of tactical turn-based games and roguelikes. Oh, past self, how naive you were.
The best incident to sum this whole thing up: on the easiest difficulty setting, in two not particularly challenging dungeons, I lost two grave robbers to bad RNG, back-to-back. Losing a unit in DD means losing hours of grinding and fine-tuning, not to mention the gold you've spent training that unit up. In the end it just feels like a waste of time. I understand that DD is meant to be challenging and stressful, but at a certain point it no longer seems worth the time and effort. 
I respect the game for what it is and I appreciate that my friends really love it, but I'm not going to recommend it to anyone. I'd rather spend my time on something based more on skill than random chance.

150578768.review:
CORTO : Si, compralo, a que coño esperas?, pillate los DLCs tambien, no te vas a decepcionar.
LARGO :

El dibujo y la dirección artística son simplemente excepcionales. Los gráficos en estilo de cómic gótico dan vida a los personajes y entornos de una manera que es a la vez hermosa y perturbadora. Cada trazo y sombra contribuye a esa atmósfera intensamente inmersiva, sumergiendo al jugador en un mundo donde la desesperación y la oscuridad son palpables.

Sin embargo, lo que hace que "Darkest Dungeon" sea más que un festín visual es su enfoque innovador en el estrés y la cordura como elementos fundamentales del juego. La dificultad aquí no solo radica en las batallas desafiantes o en la gestión de recursos, sino en el manejo de la salud mental de tus héroes. La presión constante, el terror y la brutalidad de las mazmorras impactan profundamente en la psique de tus personajes, y debes equilibrar cuidadosamente su cordura mientras luchan por la supervivencia.

En resumen, "Darkest Dungeon" es una joya artística que no solo cautiva con su estética oscura y detallada, sino que también desafía con su enfoque innovador en el estrés y la cordura como elementos cruciales del juego. Es una experiencia que trasciende lo visual para sumergirte en un viaje emocional único y apasionante.

Tambien puedes poner mods de tetas y monas chinas, por lo que si te gusta eso es un punto más a favor.

150392776.review:
I played 60 hours. I played on the 'easiest' difficulty. I was drawn to this game by the very unique and beautiful art style, fantastic music, and great storytelling. I was aware this game has a reputation for being difficult. I even installed various mods to make it easier because I wanted a casual experience.

It wasn't too bad at first, but turns out the game gets 'more difficult' as you progress by turning up the terrible game mechanics to an 11. Enemies start dodging ALL of your attacks, oneshotting or two shotting your entire party with critical hits back to back, the enemy always out speeds you later in the game and always goes first. Traditional elements of strategy you may see in other turn based rpgs becomes less and less important as you progress.

It feels absolutely helpless and there's seriously no fun in throwing your highest level heroes at certain dungeons over and over again and having them all die. You spent 15 hours and went through 10 dungeons to level up a fresh party to go after a higher level dungeon? LOL here comes some terrible rng to throw away all of your efforts. Hard games are fun when they feel fair, and you feel rewarded for overcoming the challenge. There's none of that here. Only a smidgen of relief when you finally get lucky and don't get screwed over by unlucky 'randomness'.

Final straw for me was losing an entire party of max level heroes, to back to back crits from a basic mob enemy. The basic baddie put my entire team on 'deaths door' in one hit, the turn order reset and he immediately took another turn and proceeded to wipe my party.

I write this after having just finally beaten the main story. Hands shaking and heart pounding out of my chest, for a game that's all about turn based combat, few games have pushed me quite like Darkest Dungeon has.

Deceptively simple but MADDENINGLY complex. I truly felt like I was descending into insanity the farther I sought to understand the game mechanics and how to improve, but it never felt unfair.  Sure there were bad rolls or bad RNG but it was all able to be mitigated. DD rewards players that persist and seek to improve from mistakes as you will quite literally see the results of that persistence materialize before you in successful expeditions. It's not a game where you can just brute force your way through, but the way things pay off with careful planning is sheer ecstasy. 

I'm laughing on a pile of bones and a mountain of corpses, both enemies and my own troops at this road's final end and although the cost was great, I feel better for having pushed myself through it rather than putting it down.

I guess I should give that second game a shot...

149938548.review:
KickStarter Bias Reviews

This is another one of these 90%+ games in from kickstarter that is actually an awful game, gameplay wise at its core. I pretty much knew this going in and waited 7 years before I got the game heavily discounted to finally see if what I saw was true. 

My biggest gripe with this game is it is incredibly slow and this is coming from some one who has invested tons of hours into many video games. The game has heavy theme and not much else its dark depressing which is not something I mind but if your going to make your game long there has to be more than just that to keep one playing. 

So many things in this game have arbitrary constraints there is close to zero creativity allowed from the player making you start to not care one bit about your characters in this rpg at all. The theme menu system is total garbage and Im guessing they changed it alot in their sequel game.

The game is littered with bad RNG design and Bugs I consistently put my team in order only for them to be out of order which matters alot in this game. It all feels very early access as if there is a big beginning to the game that was planned but never made it to inspire you to go through this gruelling marathon of monsters etc but there isnt.

JRpgs in recent decades have come a long way addressing issues like status effects not mattering and there are now many great ones out there. It feels as if they were attempting to focus on status effects in a big way here gameplaywise but in a way that feels they have never played an rpg before in their lives because it ignores so much of what the gameplay industry has done right in the past. 

If you get this game for free I still would not recommend as its a massive time sink for very little reward, I'm pretty surprised theres a sequel to this but it has become a trend where ego centric devs desperate to save face endlessly go back to fix there first child just like no mans sky. That kind of redemption is not going to happen here because I think overall this game reminds up why status effects should never really be the core of any game its just not fun simply put even if you are a goth gamer.

149860996.review:
This is a great game, BUT... Some things are too RNG dependent.
- You finished your mission with 0 stress on anyone? Nice, here take a bunch of negative quirks and diseases out of nowhere;
- You put a mark on yourself hoping that enemies will attack this character? Nah, they will decide to attack random targets anyway:
- You boosted your dodge to ridiculous numbers like 140 dodge? It's fine, but you will be hit anyway. Probably it is unfair talking about it, because the game doesn't show us accuracy of enemies in percentage, but I suppose that here is a fixed chance to land a hit in any case;
- You also can crit almost every hit even if your crit chance is lower than 20%, same goes for enemies. And you can easily do misses the entire round even if the chance to hit is more than 80%. This game, similar to XCOM, often makes you doubt what real chances actually are. Same goes with Death Blow resist, where 87% (cap) is nothing. and where you can send 0 level rookies to their death, and they just won't die for few rounds.
- The dice roll that is added to character's speed (1d8, I believe) is just straight RNG trash, it makes you to not care about speed stat at all, because it doesn't matter. 

Another annoying thing is the Shrieker. If you will lose randomly 1 hero with ancestor relic, without possibility to recover it, it will be not lost, but insteat stolen by Shrieker. And you can't take it back until it steals 8 of your trinkets (which is silly), so you HAVE to give 6 trash trinkets to rookies and send them to death in order to trigger Shrieker event. Otherwise you will just finish the game and still will never regain your items. It is tedious to say the least. Before Shrieker was implemented, you just lost those items and had to obtain it in another long 5 lvl dungeon.
Also, there is a smaller bug where the number of week in graveyard will be always incorrect if the person dies after you already was in Farmstead at least once. Annoying, but it wasn't fixed in years, and seems like players don't care either.

As an old player in this game, I also miss times when Jester wasn't so finale-oriented, where his solo was actually useful, where Grave Robber didn't have useless stealth and instead she had her dodge boost with ONE step back, where Leper/Plague Doctor/Man-at-Arms didn't have one-time-use skills and could stack them... Also, in Farmstead one-time skills don't work properly, because game thinks that the entire bar at the top - is one battle, so you end up never using them.

As for Endless harvest... Man, I feel so many missed opportunities. It could be something similar to Torghast from WoW, or Simulated Universe from Star Rail... Or it could be even difficulty that increases itself with every iteration, like in Diablo 3. But instead there is just a path to Sleeper, and after that there is nothing interesting at all, you just can leave. And if at the start you still could try to go as far as you can, for curiosity, then they implemented "endgame conditions", which killed this potentially great game mode completely.

Darkest Dungeon isn't just a game; it's a journey into the abyss that grips you from the start. The hand-drawn art style is not only visually stunning but also contributes to the game's immersive atmosphere. The unforgiving nature of the game, coupled with the ever-looming threat of permadeath, adds a level of tension that's both exhilarating and nerve-wracking.

The narrations, delivered with haunting gravitas, further enhance the game's atmosphere, making it an unforgettable experience. 10/10

Darkest Dungeon Review

Audio: 10/10 - superb soundtrack and voice acting

Balance: 7/10 - frustratingly difficult, but that is the point of the game and it does warn you as such

Design: 7/10 - systems are fairly easy to learn and understand but more directions would be helpful

Fun: 6/10 - occasionally straddles the line between fun and infuriating

Gameplay: 7/10 - gameplay is pretty good, a nice throwback to old turn-by-turns and dungeon crawlers

Graphics: 10/10 - haunting and gorgeous artwork

Extras: 9/10 - good DLCs that adds a multiplayer mode and new storylines

Playtime: 7/10 - long playtime, but the difficulty and grindiness can lead to frequent rage-quits

Stability: 10/10 - I’ve never witnessed any bugs or crashes

Story: 10/10 - Lovecraftian horror and lore, Cthulhu-esque madness, all of it great

Total: 83 slow and insidious killers out of 100

149290678.review:
Neat game, but it isn't really a roguelike/roguelite.

It's pretty much an RPG really.

There's roguelike-ish elements in that you can take risks discovering stuff in the dungeons, you can build a party with a bunch of different classes (there's legit like 16 of them), different accessories for the classes, a currency you use to upgrade a "base" (meta progression in the estate itself), risk vs reward with the light/dark mechanic, etc.

But I don't really qualify it as a roguelike. There are no runs and every quest you go on WILL have an affect on your next one. Whether it be a character getting stressed out and needing to unwind back at the estate, having a party die in a dungeon and losing all them AND their equipment, getting a negative quirk, etc.

Honestly, I love this game's aesthetics and battle systems, but oh my god does management of the estate and the long-term consequences of runs suck. I honestly love the idea, but it makes bad RNG and experimentation so much more punishing.

The fun of roguelikes is being able to fail a run due to your mistakes, yet being able to come out of it stronger for the next run because you learned something new from your past mistakes. Here it feels like you have all the downsides of a loss in any other roguelike and MORE without any of the plus sides of it (okay fine, maybe you'll learn/discover a new thing or two in a run, but it may not be enough to leave you wanting more). 

This game is waaaaay too punishing. Some of you may like it, but believe me when I say, that if you don't have much time on your hands, this game will do nothing but make you want to tear your hair out.

Honestly, if you like something like X-com and want something like that, but the characters can go insane, the combat is turn-based and on a way smaller grid, and you personally don't care if a game repeatedly kicks you when you're down and occasionally spits on you while it's at it, I think you'll definitely enjoy this game.

Everyone else though, proceed with risk. They murdered some of my favorite characters in the blink of an eye and left one party member live to tell the tale. On one hand, it wasn't like it was a scripted event, it WAS partially my fault, as I could've just left the dungeon to escape with them (even if it would've given them more stress/I would've missed out on some rewards), but dang it they all died in like one turn...

NOTE: Traits and quirks are fun, as having a character's only way to relieve stress be time in a brothel, only to then develop "deviant tastes" banning them from said brothels is hilarious. If I end up losing that character I'm uninstalling this game and never playing it again (i removed the quirk limiting them to brothels but left their "deviant tastes" just because I find it funny), though, I'm sure the devs probably know that and are probably dying laughing at the fact that the game is as punishing as it is. I just wish managing party members wasn't so tedious, though, I've heard that they've changed the second game to be MORE like a roguelike, so I can't wait to check that out some day.

I hope some day I'll come back to this review and change it into a recommendation, but for now, as someone with not as much time as they used to have to just themselves and with games that I generally just find to be more fun, I'll just leave this as a "don't recommend" for anyone who has heard this game is great, but not enough of the people telling them that this game is actually pretty grindy and not that much like a roguelike.

Feel free to tell me to go die in the comments though. I'd love to learn how to have more fun with this game and hate it when I see others having fun with something but feel like I can't enjoy as much myself.

149289162.review: I love the whole vibe of this game, the comic book style art, the creepy, lovecraftian horror theme. And the voice narration really is what stands out the most. It's over the top, dramatic, and I am here for it.  The gameplay itself is addictive as hell (I'm 20 hrs in, and I literally can't stop playing). It has interesting combat mechanics, and a huge amount of different character classes to choose from. The game encourages you to try different party combinations as quite often your characters become stressed out and need to take time off, forcing you to try other character combinations instead, so it keeps the combat interesting. There's no SAVE feature here either, so if one of your characters die, they are dead for good, which really adds to the tension when you are exploring the dungeons. When it comes to investigating objects in the dungeons, like opening treasure chests or looking inside a bag, there's a risk that investigating something might harm you, but it could potentially benefit you too. You just never know what the game is going to throw at you, and I love that! If you like turn based RPGs, then give this game a try, it really is surprisingly good!

"𝓡𝓮𝓬𝓾𝓮𝓻𝓭𝓪 𝓺𝓾𝓮 𝓮𝓵 𝓮𝔁𝓬𝓮𝓼𝓸 𝓭𝓮 𝓬𝓸𝓷𝓯𝓲𝓪𝓷𝔃𝓪 𝓮𝓼 𝓾𝓷 𝓪𝓼𝓮𝓼𝓲𝓷𝓸 𝓵𝓮𝓷𝓽𝓸 𝓮 𝓲𝓷𝓼𝓲𝓭𝓲𝓸𝓼𝓸"

Darkest Dungeon ofrece una experiencia muy entretenida y adictiva de principio a fin (aunque esto último puede adelantarse fácilmente debido al endiablado "RNG" que el juego establece como su pilar principal). Ha sido muy mencionado junto con el ojito derecho de FromSoft a la hora de hablar del tópico de la dificultad en los videojuegos, tiene 3 modos de desafío para así poder ajustar la dificultad al gusto de cada jugador, lo cual ayuda a evitar una mala experiencia y nos aporta rejugabilidad.

Los controles son muy sencillos, puedes probarlo prácticamente en cualquier ordenador, da muchas horas de entretenimiento, tiene un modo online para poder competir con otros jugadores.

Con varios DLC´s con soporte oficial en la Workshop de Steam, una comunidad enorme y creciendo, así como una enorme cantidad de contenido relacionado con la historia oficial del juego, como los cómics que publicó RedHook Studios para explicar el origen de cada uno de los personajes.

No te lo pierdas si te gusta Lovecraft, la saga Souls, los juegos de terror/intriga, de combate por turnos/estrategia o si te apetece un reto con el que sufrir en cada error y celebrar cada victoria.

149088721.review:
No game is perfect, but this one comes very close.  This game promises a difficult challenge & dark atmosphere, delivering on both flawlessly.  There is no protagonist, nobody is a hero, just normal people struggling the best they can to overcome unnatural horrors, their own mortality & the fragility of their own minds.  Even if you do everything right & play perfectly, a single roll of the dice will still inevitably lead to somebody's permanent end.

Replay value is extraordinarily high, with higher difficulty modes offering more mechanics, harsher penalties & new restrictions and limitations.  With one of the largest workshops full of DLC that I've personally seen & mods being constantly added & updated, you have a near-limitless source of ways to make the game fresh & interesting.  Furthermore, mods do NOT disable achievements, so feel free & have at it.

Easily one of my favorite games of all time.

149073767.review:
This game can be hard.  Like... unfairly, punishingly hard.  You will experience loss that will set you back a couple hours and then some.  The heroes come in by the caravan load and many enter the dungeons never to return.  There are some nasty surprises in store in the early game, and nastier still in the late game that will have you pulling your hair out.  RNG-sus will drive your party to madness and mutilate them one by one.  It's hard.

You can get good, though.  Your growing roster of varied heroes will improve in skill and through careful management of their afflictions and quirks.  Trinkets and baubles in careful measure will pull the party through the tightest situations.  Your decisions in supplying the party will make or break each foray into the darkest dungeons, and you will learn to mitigate the losses.

Holy shoot, it looks good.  All the grisly beasts, fungal growths, bloodthirsty marauders, shadowy shamblers, and spooky scary skeletons are illustrated and animated just right in a sharp comic book style that just oozes with that eldritch charm one might seek out on the brink of madness.  Our heroes look just as good whether they're losing their minds or experiencing a sudden pulse of courage, and in your respective rage or relief you'll feel those swings personally.  The level design visually fits right in, against the backdrop of a rundown hamlet to serve as your upgrade-able base camp, as your parties delve into a handful of impressively oppressive areas, all beautifully rendered, each with their own slew of specialized hordes.

Story's got some good spook to it.  Check out the trailers for a taste, though I would have liked to see some more storied animation within the game, it's still a great tale, mostly delivered through our ancestor's narration during the occasional loading screen.

In conclusion:  It's hard.  You might have a bad time.  Play it.

148873174.review:
Darkest Dungeon has stood the test of time as one of my favorite games of all time. The difficulty curve on the experience can be rough at the start and smooths out over the course of many estates. Each character feels unique in its archetype and sub-archetypes that form from the combination of various skill, other champions, and trinkets that you discover over the course of a run. Risk often translates to a tangible reward in the dungeons where "push you luck" can line your pockets with gold, trinkets, or crests, or you may wind up with four fresh graves in the graveyard. After a few estates, it can be a wholly different experience upping the difficult from Radiant to Darkest to Stygian (Bloodmoon with the Crimson Court DLC). You may have to re-imagine how you fought previous encounters when life limits, darkness increases. or a time limit are imposed. All of these factors helped shape Darkest Dungeon into a memorable experience that I come back to every year.

In addition to the base game, I suggest grabbing [in order] The Shield Breaker, Color of Madness, and Crimson Court DLCs. Shield breaker adds an incredibly useful and powerful companion that has a unique interaction in the dungeons. Color of Madness adds an optional 'endless' dungeon grind that pauses the normal time progression while keeping some of the risks. And finally Crimson Court adds in the powerful Flagellant companion, multi level mega dungeon encounters, and a ramping difficulty to the base game with bloodsucker infestations and the withering crimson curse itself. I think this order provides the best evolving gameplay experience in difficulty; however, this is not the order of my personal enjoyment. Above and beyond I personally enjoy the difficulty added by the Crimson Court the most. However it is very much not new player friendly. If engaged with too early you can feel overwhelmed with wasting champions and the punishing mega dungeons. And if engaged with too late you will miss out on incredibly powerful trinkets and be bogged down by repeated stress relieving activity reduction events in town. Color of Madness feels lacking to me, but I enjoy the trinkets before I get to the mid game. And the Shield Breaker can sometimes feel borderline busted near the mid game to late game. 

You will lose. The game will feel like it is picking on you. You will get overwhelmed. This gameplay style isn't for everyone and its okay if its not for you. But if you like this kind of challenge I promise that when its all said and done and the last champions head into the final layer of the Darkest Dungeon, you will feel rewarded.

Just taking a look at my hours in this game probably tells you how much I enjoy it. For all it's flaws and especially the ones that it had earlier in its life before some of the changes made to combat and the introduction of mechanics like the Crimson Curse from DLC, I still think this game has a warm place in my heart as one of my favorite games of all time. 

The aesthetics and artstyle alone are nearly enough to carry it for me, and it so sincerely captures the feeling of the games opening statement. Darkest Dungeon is a game about making the best out of bad situations. You will almost always be fighting an uphill battle, combat is stacked completely against you and you're likely to get completely screwed over by something you couldn't account for. 

This might sound absolutely terrible, and undoubtedly for some people this will be a frustrating and completely unfair game that is only hailed as "Difficult" because of the RNG involved in combat, etc. This is what I love about the game though. I am absolute masochist and always yearn for RPGs and tactical games that absolutely bust your balls and demand your A-Game. Sometimes through means that are usually seen as pretty cheap. X-Com comes to mind. 

If this sounds like you, buy the game.

It breaks you down to your base components and then builds you back up again through careful planning and gaining a deeper understanding of how the game works. It makes you confident, and eventually should you not heed The Ancestors warnings, it makes you careless and sloppy. Overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer, and it lurks behind every victory, arrogant decision, and careless choice you make. 148300087.review:
[h1]Summary[/h1]
A near masterpiece of eldritch, Gothic horror. Dread and hopelessness without the generic horror genre cheese. Wayne June, you are a god, ‘nuf said. Expect several runs figuring out how to build good parties, and that thrill of victory when you win…on easy. Strategy and planning will carry you a long way, but the excessive randomness is why I need to put this game down now for good. It was a great run though.
[hr][/hr]
I hate to start off by calling [i]Darkest Dungeon[/i] a wonderful thematic experience because that [i]usually[/i] implies other elements are mediocre at best. [i]Darkest Dungeon[/i] is a near masterpiece because it is a great game that is [b]also[/b] deeply entrenched in Gothic horror.   It’s dark, moody, filled with your nightmares…and yet never relies on gore or cheesy jump scares to make you feel hopeless, desperate, and out of your depth. Surely this must be a full immersion VR, right? Nope…side-scrolling exploration with turn-based combat and town management. The thematic elements are simply [b]*Chef’s Kiss*[/b].

Wayne June as the Narrator also needs a special shoutout. He is the *[i][b]perfect[/b][/i]* voice to set the game’s mood. The Narrator is the only voice in the game and he is your dead ancestor, heralds your accomplishments and failures, and even narrates combat. Despite being the only voice in the game, playing for over 200 h, and having only 3-ish dozen routine lines…I will literally [b]never[/b] tire of hearing Wayne June shout [i]“Executed with impunity!”[/i].

Gameplay is overall good, but very hard…at first. Be prepared to lose several games just figuring out the system. But this is eldritch, Gothic horror set in an ironman style roguelike game. If you are getting into the setting, it wouldn’t be right if you beat the game on the first go…or second…or fifth. Also, you have to know when, and be willing, to abandon the dungeon because things just went really badly. And you will feel that loss, because you won’t come back with the resources to recover…much less make any improvements.

I put 40 h into the game before I had figured enough out to take my first real crack at it. Even then, I was still missing some key pieces. There are lots of ways to build fun and very effective adventuring parties. Once you understand how all the pieces come together, the roles your different party members can take on, the game becomes…not easy, but winnable.  

You are constantly trying to make the best of a bad situation. Heroes are frequently stressed to the edge of insanity, and you still have to put together an effective roster for the next dungeon. After you pay to give your heroes some much needed downtime (they can’t adventure), you have to make hard decisions about what to do with the little remaining gold. Buy one hero better armor? Upgrade a few skills? Make future healing cheaper? I love it.

[i]Darkest Dungeon[/i] isn’t perfect. There are a handful of minor gripes about mechanics I don’t like. Ambush, for example. If you get ambushed, it’s super bad…especially when you are still learning, avoid it [b]at all costs![/b] Then when you ambush baddies you go first, which seems good…but then they get 2 turns in a row. To me, that is a penalty. I would rather manage spread out damage versus spending the rest of the fight recovering from getting the ever-living shit kicked out of me (ambush fights frequently take [i]longer[/i] than regular fights because of this).

The game also indexes [b]very[/b] heavily into randomness…and virtually everything in the game has a random element. Want a Jester so you can reduce dungeon stress? You might not get one for 6…12…20 weeks (week = game turn, one dungeon per week). Need your Crusader to come back from the bar for the next run because he’s your only tank? Too bad…no telling when he will get back from his bender. Randomness is what ends up being [i]Darkest Dungeon’s[/i] Achilles’s heel, and prevents me from putting it in my top tier of games.

Once you are an expert or master of the game, you figure out how to cope with the randomness. Mostly by making sure the worst situation is still within the capability of your party. And if you chose to take a risky run into a high-level dungeon, you do it knowing that you already have the resources to recover. At this point I can guarantee a finish on Darkest difficulty run within a reasonable time frame, and without much angst or hand wringing…and because of that the game has lost a bit of magic for me.

And this is where the biggest problem comes in.  To increase the difficulty, you not only get tougher dungeons, but you get a limited number of deaths (12) and game weeks (86).  This is bad because the randomness might prevent you from getting the things you need to succeed. I went 10 weeks without getting a healer in my recruitment tent. Plus, the final dungeons become so hard that a single crit on the wrong guy will one-shot them. There are builds that help negate this…but that relies on getting the right trinkets to drop….  In the end, you might spend all your time and you literally cannot win, even with the right builds and playstyle.  That’s ok for a game that is 2-3 hours a run…not 20-30.

Despite how much I do like this game, I have to set it down now forever. The lower difficulties no longer feel like [i]Darkest Dungeon[/i], and the higher difficulties rely too much on randomness for the win/loss.  But I do have to say…[b]man, what a ride.[/b]

Posso afirmar que a Red Hook fez um ótimo trabalho desenvolvendo o jogo, uma experiência única, nunca vi um jogo executar tão bem a ideia de "suas ações são permanentes, heróis VÃO morrer, risco resulta em recompensas e/ou perdas altas, você NUNCA tem certeza se você vai conseguir suceder ou simplesmente ser destruído numa quest".

Eu vou tentar ser o mais grosso modo e menos aprofundado o possível nessa review, até porque eu quero que você jogue o jogo por conta própria, mas eu posso te garantir que:

1: Se você gosta de RPGs de turno (e até mesmo os de mesa), você provavelmente vai gostar de Darkest Dungeon, já que ele reinventa várias mecânicas de RPGs tradicionais e a maneira que elas se interagem.

2: Provavelmente você vai ficar perdido no começo do jogo (que nem eu quando comecei a jogar), sem entender muito o que está acontecendo, pois o loop da gameplay é meio difícil de pegar a manha no começo mesmo, já que Darkest Dungeon reinventa tantas mecânicas e simplesmente cospe elas na sua cara e espera que você entenda. Não é que as mecânicas são ruins, mas a forma que os devs escolheram pra apresentar essas mecânicas pro jogador não é intuitiva.

Fora os adendos que passei antes, Darkest Dungeon é um ótimo RPG, e você deve pelo menos dar uma chance a ele se você ficou remotamente interessado, pois vale a pena (mesmo se você odiar no começo).

147878967.review:
In the shadowy recesses of modern entertainment, where few dare to tread for fear of the abyssal madness that lurks therein, exists a digital monstrosity known as "Darkest Dungeon". Crafted by the enigmatic minds at Red Hook Studios, this interactive experience serves not as a mere game, but as an eldritch tome chronicling the frailty of human sanity and the cosmic horrors that imperil our feeble existence.

Much like the ancient and forbidden texts that I have often written about, Darkest Dungeon is not for the faint of heart. From its outset, one is thrust into a macabre tale of ancestral sin, wherein the player becomes custodian of a forsaken hamlet and its doomed denizens. Each foray into the labyrinthine catacombs, the profane warrens, or the eldritch weald tests not only one's strategic prowess but also the very limits of human resilience.

The art, a phantasmagoria of grotesque designs and despair-inducing landscapes, evokes a chilling sense of foreboding. The twisted visages of the heroes and monsters alike are reminiscent of the incomprehensible beings that haunt my own tales — embodiments of unfathomable cosmic terror. Furthermore, the narration, delivered in a grave and haunting timbre, underscores the ceaseless dread that permeates this dark digital domain.

Yet, where Darkest Dungeon truly excels is in its exploration of human fragility. Heroes, though valiant in their endeavors, are by no means impervious to the psychological traumas of their quests. Stress, paranoia, hopelessness — these are as palpable foes as any tentacled monstrosity or undead marauder. One must navigate not just the external threats, but also the internal demons that threaten to unravel the very fabric of one's party.

Critics may decry its punishing difficulty or the merciless RNG that can cast even the most well-laid plans into the abyss. But it is in these moments of despair, where all seems lost and the void beckons, that the true essence of Lovecraftian horror is realized. In confronting the incomprehensible and the inevitable decay of hope, one is forced to reckon with the inherent meaninglessness of existence in a universe that is at best indifferent and at worst, malevolent.

In conclusion, "Darkest Dungeon" stands as a digital testament to mankind's eternal struggle against both the known and unknown horrors of the cosmos. It is not merely a game, but a journey into the very heart of darkness, where one must confront not only the external monstrosities but also the innermost fears and frailties of the human psyche. Those with a penchant for cosmic horror and a tolerance for despair will find it an experience unparalleled in its chilling authenticity.

147798874.review:
Feels like what a dungeon-crawling experience should be like. Filled with unknown variables, unexpectedly brutal, dark, and full of high stakes. I'm pretty calm and collected with games, but this is one of the rare few that actually makes me feel like raging at times - I mean that in a good way, because my losses are usually due to me being careless or taking a risk, after an absence of bad luck giving me a false sense of security. As the (really good) voice narrator in the game occasionally says, "Overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer" 

That aside, the modding community is also great - base game has a good selection of classes (I'm guessing something like 15?), nearly all of them viable. With mods, even excluding the... questionable mods and being selective with classes that are a fairly close fit to the theme/balancing of the original, I'm currently sitting at over 100 classes. Not to mention extra content as well, such as one of them adding a chance for chests to turn into a mimic, and some even adding entirely new regions with the quality of official DLC expansions.

147794966.review: I’m of two minds with Darkest Dungeon. On one hand, it’s a game for masochists. Suffering is kind of the point. Darkest Dungeon doesn’t sugarcoat this; however, I don’t feel like Darkest Dungeon completely hits the mark, nor is it entirely honest. The biggest issue with getting into Darkest Dungeon isn’t the ‘difficulty’, which is really just excessive RNG, but how much the game relishes in wasting your time. Whether it’s crawling back through 7 rooms/halls of a dungeon you already explored cause you picked the wrong fork in a path, wasting turns in combat chewing through corpses ‘cause none of your characters can attack the remaining enemies, or wasting turns re-arranging characters ‘cause they don’t have abilities to dynamically re-arrange, or needing to wait for the stage coach to bring you a new healer after the one you’d almost got to max level died to a ridiculous cascade of RNG you had no opportunity to react to, or worse yet, having your entire party wipe and having to start grinding new ones up from square one. It’s Roguelite, so a degree of repetition should be expected, but the scale to which you have to repeat things, whether over the course of the entire game, or even in a single dungeon, and the slow pace at which the game runs to ‘build atmosphere’, is a painful combination. Not masochistic, ‘oh this requires a grand strategy’, not masochistic, ‘oh this requires razor sharp reflexes’, not even masochistic ‘oh I made a mistake and now I’m set back for it’, it’s masochistic because once you feel like your time is being wasted all immersion is gone and all that’s left is frustration… and yet I played over a hundred hours regardless, thinking back on my time with it I fondly remember the striking visuals, and dismal setting, and I do recommend the game, all because my time wasting gripes can be mitigated enough by workshop mods that increase the speed of dungeon movement and combat animations, among other things. Darkest Dungeon’s community has supported the game well, and I honestly think if you’re going to play it, you need at least the move and combat speed up mods to make it playable, but if that’s not to your satisfaction, there’s a world of mods from additional variety in graphics, to new character classes, and there’s even an overhaul mod that has its own store page, plenty to tailor the experience to your preferences.

It's a good game, but it's absolutely impossible to make any progress. I've played all on one save for these 68 hours and am at something like week 48. I still don't have anyone over level 2, because it's absolutely impossible to progress in this game. The only way you can complete dungeons after a while is by pushing through with all four members having an affliction, then you have to spend almost all the money you earned fixing them up, so in the meantime you have to use level 0s right off the stagecoach who either die or get so stressed out you have to cure their afflictions as well, so you're now in the hole again, spending all the money you just earned. You can't ever afford to upgrade anything because all your money is going into fixing everyone up from the last dungeon. By the time you get some level 2s and send them to a harder dungeon, you get more money but have to spend more fixing them all up again.

It's a vicious cycle that can never end. It's fun, but it's easy to get demoralized because there's just no way to make real progress in this game. Get it if if sounds good, but know you'll never, ever win no matter how much effort and time you put into it.

147723153.review:
I was instantly hooked when I started the game, but it all falls apart as soon as you make a mistakes later on.

This game is well known for the permanent death mechanic. Early on and in the midgame, this is a fantastic mechanic that really punishes poor play while still giving the player plenty of opportunities to recover from their mistakes.

Later in the game, though... If you loses a level 5 or 6 hero, you are looking at literal hours of grinding just to get back to where you were. It isn't interesting. It isn't fun. It doesn't create unique situations. It wastes the player's time with mindless grinding. By this point, you have most of the best trinkets, have seen almost every boss, and are just trying to finish up the game. Being forced to spend hours grinding for levels is not a fun mechanic, and the game does nothing to make leveling any faster.

If you have tons of time on your hands, maybe this isn't such a terrible thing. Though, if you have that much time, play something more engaging and interesting.

I want to love this game, but I just can't bring myself to finish it after losing a few max level characters to a combination of poor play on my part and an absurd amount of critical hits. Level grinding is an outdated mechanic that ruins the endgame of Darkest Dungeon.

147424752.review: Ruin has come to our family. You remember our venerable house, opulent and imperial. Gazing proudly from its stoic perch above the moor. I lived all my years in that ancient, rumor-shadowed manor. Fattened by decadence and luxury. And yet, I began to tire of conventional extravagance. Singular, unsettling tales suggested the mansion itself was a gateway to some fabulous and unnamable power. With relic and ritual, I bent every effort towards the excavation and recovery of those long-buried secrets, exhausting what remained of our family fortune on swarthy workmen and sturdy shovels. At last, in the salt-soaked crags beneath the lowest foundations we unearthed that damnable portal of antediluvian evil. Our every step unsettled the ancient earth but we were in a realm of death and madness! In the end, I alone fled laughing and wailing through those blackened arcades of antiquity. Until consciousness failed me. You remember our venerable house, opulent and imperial. It is a festering abomination! I beg you, return home, claim your birthright, and deliver our family from the ravenous clutching shadows of the [b]Darkest Dungeon[/b]

145679856.review:
--Pros--
1. Amazing selection of heroes with great abilities focused around certain party compositions

2. Ancestors narrations pull you into an incredibly atmospheric world of certain horror and mind numbing insanity

3. DLC is so much fun and so well done, easy to get into and hard to master

4. Turn based combat revolving around dice rolls, much like dungeons and dragons or other roll 20 games with a unique stress mechanic 

5. Artwork and Soundtrack are beautiful, dark and horrifically interesting. 

6. PVP mode for those willing to endure the pain for personal glory (The Butcher's Circus)

7. Large selection of skills and trinkets allow cool variations of the same hero (minus Vestal, she's stuck healing)

8. The poor miller, thrice a victim. The seasons took his livelihood, I took his land. And now, uncountable years later, the comet has taken his humanity. My only regret is I did not live to see that shoddy mill smashed to pieces by the miraculous bounty I reaped from beyond the void.. (The Endless Harvest)

                                                                   --Cons--
1. Insanely difficult, increasingly more punishing as you progress the story line

2. The Butchers Circus PVP mode is heavily RNG reliant and many of the best trinkets are locked behind leveling making your first games completely miserable

3. RNG can wipe you incredibly fast, especially in the final dungeon. Overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer..

Personal Rating: 4/5

145669643.review: Top 10 game. Top 5 game. Maybe even top 3 games of all time for me. Such a focused, intimidating, and endearing little journey. It's turn based dungeon crawling at its finest. The gameplay will demand you make do with whatever you have or fail. Sometimes, do all that and you still fail. Plan around the unknown, plan for what you do know, and press on to riches or ruin. All of the classes feel useful in spite of some definite stand outs. They also all feel fun to play. The sound design is top notch. The music choreographs foreboding, but mostly safe havens, tense treks through threatening hallways, uneasy firelit reprieves, and desperate battles. The stand out feature of the game's audio is the inclusion of the narrator, Wayne June, who brings flavor and injects some meaning in all that you do, filling in the blanks where the game might leave empty spaces or undefined ideas. The art direction and design is an endearing marriage of pop up picture books while also having a dark fantastical edge that makes it visually memorable and enjoyable to look at. If you're looking for an engaging gameplay experience, consider paying The Hamlet a visit. The road may take you to hell and other damnable places, but you'll have a surprisingly good, if a bit anxious, time purifying your ancestral home.

In time, I have come to know the tragic extent of his failings...



Addendum:
I could not really get into this game until I accepted what it states in the opening scene. Heroes will die, quests will fail. The one constant is your hamlet, from which diligent upgrades will make those losses irrelevant. Utilize the idle stress reduction between weeks, constantly bring fresh recruits, and send them in screaming with minimal supplies. Don't worry about letting broken heroes go.

Upgrading the stagecoach to supply level 4 heroes will allow you to quickly fill your roster with max level characters, and losing them doesn't feel quite so bad. Level 4 heroes come with weapons, armor, and skills already upgraded, saving thousands in gold. I would not waste your resources on upgrades or stress reduction until you have them. Apart from that, tons of content to explore and conquer, and a free mod that essentially feels like a perfect sequel to the base game. I am nearing 200 hours between the two, and will likely hit 300 before completing The Black Reliquary mod and my Bloodmoon save. What a game!

Title: A Perilous Descent into Madness - My Review of "Darkest Dungeon"

In an age where mediocrity is often the norm, "Darkest Dungeon" stands as a brilliant beacon of excellence, offering players an experience that transcends the boundaries of typical gaming. Developed by Red Hook Studios, this masterpiece of gothic horror and strategic game-play demands your attention and rewards your perseverance in ways that few games ever manage.

From the very moment you step foot into the grim hamlet surrounding the foreboding estate, you are immediately ensnared by the game's mesmerizing atmosphere. The haunting art style, replete with detailed character designs and eerie backdrops, works in harmony with the haunting musical score to create an atmosphere that is dripping with dread and unease. The feeling of being perpetually on the brink of catastrophe never dissipates, keeping you in a state of constant tension.

However, it's not just the aesthetics that set "Darkest Dungeon" apart; it's the brilliantly designed game-play mechanics that truly shine. At its core, this is a game of calculated risk and resource management. Every expedition into the depths of the estate brings with it the potential for great reward, but also the very real possibility of utter devastation. The mechanics of stress, afflictions, and quirks serve as a stark reminder of the psychological toll that dungeon delving takes on your party, deepening the connection between player and character. The result is an experience that is both punishingly difficult and exhilaratingly satisfying.

What truly sets "Darkest Dungeon" on a pedestal, however, is its unabashed commitment to challenging the player's decision-making skills. With the ever-looming threat of permadeath, each choice you make, from which heroes to recruit to which upgrades to prioritize, carries monumental weight. This unforgiving nature can be daunting, but it’s also what gives the victories a sweet taste that few other games can replicate. Triumphing over a particularly harrowing encounter or defeating a menacing boss elicits a euphoria that's difficult to match.

The narrative elements in "Darkest Dungeon" are masterfully woven into the fabric of the game-play. The narrated passages by Wayne June add a layer of gravitas to the events unfolding, and the snippets of lore you uncover as you progress hint at a vast and terrifying world just beyond the scope of your torchlight. This world-building, coupled with the personal stories of your heroes, creates a sense of immersion that is profoundly engaging.

In conclusion, "Darkest Dungeon" is not a game for the faint-hearted. It's a journey into the darkest recesses of human nature, a relentless test of strategy, and a tribute to the indomitable human spirit in the face of overwhelming odds. Red Hook Studios has crafted a timeless masterpiece that will undoubtedly be remembered for years to come. If you're seeking a gaming experience that challenges you on every level and leaves an indelible mark on your psyche, dare to venture into the abyss of Darkest Dungeon – your sanity may be tested, but your gaming library will be forever enriched.

145013588.review:
Darkest Dungeon is... really hard.

Treat the game like it hates you. I do not say this lightly, because if you play the game as if you're trying to spite the developers, it is somewhat easier. In order to really get into DD, you have to stick with a particularly grueling earlygame - something many people simply will not do. It's a frustrating game. At times, it'll feel like the game doesn't make any sense, or like you're not making any progress.

Because Darkest Dungeon HATES you. It wants you to fail. It will punish every single mistake you make, and will refuse to praise your victories. As you progress, you will be micromanaging well over 20 characters - that's 5 full teams! - in order to get their stresses down, their bad quirks removed, their equipment somewhat passable, and their skills in optimal position for success. This is an absolute logistical nightmare, since to do any of these things, you need money - lots of it, which you can only get by going deeper into the dungeons. You will lose characters. You will lose progress. The real currency of Darkest Dungeon is not artifacts or gold, but the hard-learned lessons of every mistake you make along the way. You will learn your lesson, or your future expeditions will be just as doomed as the one that taught you.

And I'm playing on EASY!

But it can be done. Stick with it. Make mistakes. You may have to restart a couple times. Learn every character you come across inside and out, don't be afraid to experiment, and most importantly - [b]running away is [i][u]ALWAYS[/u][/i] an option.[/b]

145004522.review:
On paper, I should hate this game. It's has turn based combat (with RNG that can fuck you in a single turn,) there are roguelike elements, the dungeons consistently turn a muted color that bothers me slightly.

Yet this may be my favorite game I've played this year. The atmosphere does a lot of heavy lifting when it comes to the elements that would bother me. Having punishing RNG and muted colors fits the oppressive Lovecraftian vibe they were going for. But I think part of the saving grace of this game is that you always have options.

Permadeath is always around the corner, but you do have the option to retreat and deal with the consequences.

More importantly, due to the expeditions being finite challenges, you aren't forced to replay large sections of the game every time you lose.

There are a lot of positives going for this game, including the systems for characters to develop personality quirks, and the randomized stress reactions, but I'm mostly just impressed that the game was able to captivate me so thoroughly with game play mechanics I dislike instead of despite them.

Play the damn game.

144831478.review:
"Darkest Dungeon" is a relentless descent into madness that has left me both exhilarated and utterly frazzled. This game is a merciless master, demanding every ounce of strategic brilliance and iron-willed determination, and I'm not sure whether to praise it or beg for mercy.

From the moment I inherited my ancestral estate, I knew I was in for a punishing experience. The game's dark and gothic atmosphere enveloped me like a shroud, and the narration, delivered with eerie gravitas, served as a constant reminder that despair lurked around every corner. The game's art style, a hauntingly beautiful blend of Lovecraftian horror and medieval darkness, only deepened the sense of foreboding.

The core gameplay in "Darkest Dungeon" is a relentless test of survival. Sending a party of heroes into the twisted depths of the estate is a game of risk and reward, where death is a constant companion. The need to manage stress, monitor health, and deal with the ever-encroaching darkness adds layers of complexity that can be both maddening and addicting.

One of the standout features is the permadeath mechanic. Losing a beloved hero, one who's been through countless battles and faced unimaginable horrors, is a gut-wrenching experience. It's a testament to the game's storytelling that each loss feels like a tragedy.

The character progression system is a double-edged sword. As heroes level up, they develop unique quirks and traits, which can be both beneficial and detrimental. It adds depth to the characters but also introduces an element of unpredictability that can turn the tide of battle for better or worse.

The game's difficulty is off the charts. Every decision, from party composition to resource management, carries consequences that can lead to disaster. It's a game that punishes mistakes with ruthless efficiency, and the learning curve can be brutal.

Furthermore, the game's narrative, delivered through journal entries and cryptic hints, adds an element of intrigue that keeps you pushing forward, even as the darkness threatens to consume your sanity.

In conclusion, "Darkest Dungeon" is a masterpiece of masochistic game design. It's a game that pushes you to the brink of despair, yet somehow keeps you coming back for more punishment. Whether you emerge victorious or succumb to the horrors that lurk in the shadows, one thing is certain: "Darkest Dungeon" is an experience that will haunt your dreams and leave you questioning your sanity.

144813961.review:
Very grindy, repetitive, tedious, and really just boring. There are elements of interesting game mechanics, but any semblance of "strategy" trying to use those mechanics is completely overwhelmed by the randomness.

Developers clearly didn't consider the gameplay ramifications of the stacked RNG: random characters, random dungeons, random loot, random hits, random misses, random effects. Everything is RANDOM. And we're talking TRUE randomness, not the balanced randomness of more enjoyable games like XCOM. 

Good games implement features to counteract their randomness, to give the player a break from too many bad rolls in a row. This game lacks any such feature. And as such, it lacks player-agency, making it barely feel like an "RPG" or even a "game". It's just a GUI for my computer to spit out random numbers, fighting itself. I, the player, am just here to click a button and see what happens next.

This is definitely a hard game to recommend for anyone not familiar with its genres.

But for anyone that wants it, this game is a very solid intersection of Gothic/Eldritch Horror, Turn-based Strategy, and Rogue-like. It's stressful, but feels rewarding when completing an excursion. The stress and campsite resting make the Turn-based strat side more interesting, juggling traditional strategies with effectively a second health bar, and the Gothic Horror side is prevalent all the way down to how the game plays.

It is a steep hill to climb, but I'd say it's worth the trek up.

144165295.review:
Un juego muy inusual, extraño, injusto y lúgubre... pero tiene algo que te atrapa.

ASPECTOS NEGATIVOS
-Te enseña poco nada más empiezas, lo que te deja vendido en innumerables ocasiones. Se trata de juego de ensayo y error, pero cuando cometes un error, duele muchísimo. Tiene una curva de dificultad muy vertical.
-En numerosas ocasiones el juego es injusto, porque se basa mucho en el azar y la probabilidad. Puedes tener un buen equipo y estrategia, que si al enemigo de turno le sale un crítico puede eliminar a un héroe tuyo de un par de golpes, lo que puede llevar a frustrar y hacer que abandones el juego. Mención especial a cuando se muere uno de tus personajes en la puerta de un boss porque ya estaba "tocado".

ASPECTOS POSITIVOS
-Una vez que pasas por el bautismo de fuego y no te has rendido, el juego te lo agradece. Una ves tienes montada la maquinaria es más fácil reponerse de los héroes que van muriendo (que no serán pocos), mejorar rápidamente su equipo y seguir hacia la victoria.
-Cuando empieza a funcionar es muy gratificante, efectuar sinergias y darle para el pelo a los enemigos que antes te metían en líos.
-La estética de juego es muy llamativa y está muy conseguida, como un cómic lúgubre y oscuro, con criaturas infernales y de conexto de terror.
-A pesar de haber pocos niveles, que se generen aleatoriamente le da un plus de originalidad, para que nunca te confíes, porque incluso la misión más fácil puede torcerse si no vas bien preparado.
-Hay mods que son una delicia, permitiéndote jugar con personajes nuevos o cambiar skines. Destaco el personaje de Kratos, Geralt de Rivia o el Cazador de Bloodborne (mi favorito), con su propio set de habilidades, objetos y skines.

En resumen, no es un juego para todos los públicos pero cuando te atrapa, no te suelta hasta que lo terminas. Las expansiones y otros modos de juego pretenden alargar su vida y rejugabilidad, aprovechando lo conseguido, pero yo me quedo principalmente con la campaña original. Sin duda recomiendo probarlo y tener algo de paciencia con él. Si te gustan los retos, es un juego muy recomendable.

Darkest Dungeon is a masterpiece that totally immerses you in its dark and haunting world. The chilling atmosphere keep you on the edge of your seat from the get-go.
Once you dive into the eerie estate, you're hooked by the gripping storytelling and wicked hand-drawn art style. The Lovecraftian touch is maintained throughout the whole game.

Customizing, and minmaxing my characters is one of my favorite things. They got quirks and flaws you need to optimise based on the challenges ahead. Its super satisfying to maintain your favorites and a big deal if you lose them.

Darkest Dungeon doesn't baby you, its the Dark Souls of dark dungeon games. It tests your strategy and creativity. Sometimes it can feel daunting if you want to sit back and relax, but you can always grind low level dungeons then.

In short, Darkest Dungeon is a must-play for anyone seeking an immersive dungeon crawling experience. Remember, overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer...

143449848.review:
The game isn't that hard once you learn what enemy parties you might encounter, their abilities and what your heroes are good at. The gimmick of the game is that you cannot prepare for everything (unless inordinate quirk locking be considered a virtue), the trinkets always have some kind of downside (or kind of useless when they don't), but the good thing is that having stuns, lots of damage, speed, accuracy, some healing and some stress healing and camp skills to heal stress makes the game a lot more managable, so the conclusion is that you want to look out for heroes that have the aforementioned things and don't interfere with each other's positioning and always can do something useful in case you get surprised or shuffled. Another factor is more related to your personal blunders like forgetting some provisions like Blood or shovels and what not, or starting a fight you can't finish (Shambler, Collector) or having to abandon the mission because your team comp couldn't get to the boss room with little damage, or letting a hero get an affliction (this usually causes a domino effect and you'll probably abandon the quest soon).
Once you harness the game mechanics and RNG to some extent, the game becomes really enjoyable. The only feasible downsides are probably grinding level 6 heroes and RNG screwing you over on a rare occasion (like your level 6 Flagellant  with 87% deathblow resist dying on the first death's door check, have fun spending an hour or two grinding a new hero with good quirks! (also a reminder that deathblow resist doesn't exist)).

143346681.review:
[h1] Darkest Dungeon is about making the most of a bad situation [/h1]
That’s the first part of the message that welcomes you into the game and I think it describes it perfectly, this game is hard sometimes even unfair but that’s why it so satisfying when you get to beat it.
Darkest Dungeon is a unique fusion of Side-scroller/RPG. I wouldn’t say it’s a roguelike, but it has permadeath once one of your heroes dies in combat is gone [spoiler] most likely [/spoiler] forever, this makes the game incredibly punishing. One bad dungeon expedition can set you back hours of gameplay towards the end of the game. The game makes an incredible emphasis on the positioning of your heroes some abilities are only available in specific rows so keeping the position of your heroes and messing up the enemies position it’s a key part of the gameplay. 
This game highly rewards knowledge and using the right tool for each situation. There’s a highly armored pig with poison resistance then bleed it to death, an annoying witch stressing your heroes bring it to the front so she can’t use their strongest attacks. Each dungeon is consistent with the kind of enemies you will be facing: 
[list]
    [*]The ruins are full of undead skeletons who are vulnerable to blight but invulnerable to bleeding
    [*]The warrens are inhabited by swine beast who are vulnerable to bledding but really hard to blight 
[/list]
And so on with each one of the locations, every battle is a little puzzle that you can approach in multiple ways according to your hero composition.
About the art style and the general setting it really hit the right spot for the general feeling of being trapped in a terrible situation, the music, the lore everything fits perfectly so if you find any of the elements of the compelling or you really like the challenges give the game a try and if you got yourself stuck don’t be ashamed to look for help in a guide or read the wiki about the game I did it myself and still today enjoy the game to a lot.
Also the modding community is full of great quality mods giving the game a lot of replayability, some modders were even hired to work in the team for Darkest Dungeon 2

143206328.review:
Just finished my first playthrough (Darkest difficulty, faster combat mod). When I first heard of Darkest Dungeon, the phrase I heard that stuck out most was "this game HATES you". After 90 hours, I'm not sure I'd agree. Rather, I'd say this game will take every opportunity you give it to screw you. DD is unquestionably mean, but not unfairly so. When things go wrong, the source can often be traced back to something you did -- characters' skills or gear is underleveled, you forgot important supplies, bad team comp, overconfidence, etc. -- and the game will happily punish you for it.

DD is a vast departure from what I normally play; I usually stick to fun, chill indie games that don't make you shake your fist at the heavens. There were times my sole motivation for finishing this game was spite. Even so, I'm glad I played DD. It drips with Gothic atmosphere, Wayne June is at the height of his powers, the breadth of viable teams adds to the potential replay value, and of course the memes are nigh endless. Even if I never touch DD again, I am part of this game now -- bound to it. Strong recommend.

It's a great game. Visually, audibly, the game mechanics. Keep luring me back. 
It feels very much like a game of Call of Cthulhu both in tone and in the punishing mechanics.

Difficulty settings are hard by default. I did NOT enjoy the game until I turned it down to 'easy' and turned off ALL additional difficulty options - THEN it became a fun game for me (others might of course like the punishing gameplay). 

The main downside - which is of course an intentional aspect of the game - is the loss of characters. So don't get too attached to them. You should, however, get attached to your hamlet (city upgrades stay, while characters die) but it feels a little weird / annoying. I think I generally like people more than buildings.

A smaller issue is how the effect of the various abilities are explained and shown. Both could do with a bit of tweaking for improved UX.

Darkest Dungeon is a Turn-based Tactical RPG that's pretty unforgiving, except for the "Death's Door" mechanic, which I think is a huge boon to the game-play.

Having to handle your different heroes Hunger, Stress and Quirks in addition to their HP makes the game far more interesting than it otherwise would be. It gives more depth and weight to the planning of your expeditions as well.

It's definitely not for everyone but if what I've described above sounds like something you like in a game then Darkest Dungeon is a very safe bet for a good gaming experience.

142814531.review:
Ultimately, I simply cannot recommend this game.  I've played it quite a few hours, which by itself might seem thumbs-up recommendation, but it really isn't.

I like the battle line style games (by which I mean the array/position of your characters in a turn-based combat has meaning).  A front line, a back line, support, damage, looking for synergies.  Nifty. Engaging even.
I've read/watched the guides and tips.  I didn't find any of it particularly of use, I've been playing these sorts of things for a while.

The reality of this game is... frustrating.  At anything higher than the easiest level, the RNG is cruel and punitive.  At the easiest level... some mild challenge (which ramped up _sharply_ for the final dungeon).  The designers should note there is a significant difference between challenging and just mean.  Not to mention a nuisance factor.  
I'm okay with taking losses if it achieves my goals.  Slogging to earn enough money to make the characters viable so they can complete the only challenges available, watching them get crushed, oft with a series of crits from the enemies and misses on my part, in the first one or two meaningless fights in a run?  When there are likely to be 5 or 6 more fights plus maybe a boss?  Ugh.  The challenge is high enough that losing even one of four characters on the way to the boss is a death sentence (in the boss fight, that's fine, I've lost 3/4 and still won, dicey though).  
Healing, especially stress healing, is sparse enough, and defenses low enough that one might think that the all damage is the way to go, but attrition will quickly show the error of that thinking.  And, ofc, the decent support classes mostly don't do enough damage &/or tank enough to make them viable on their own (as it should be, but there is a balance to be achieved in there somewhere).

Oh, and the money grind.  Painful, right up until you are flooded with it.  But did I mention the building upgrade resource grind?  Which is dependent on the RNG?  And your limited space, competing with money at every turn?  Choices matter and all that, but you truly need _everything_, right now, no exceptions, or you die trying.  Repeatedly.  Over and over.  Which might be okay... IF the losses at times didn't leave you so destitute as to be unable to continue at all.
Not workable.

And after now rage-quitting from yet another excruciating and drawn-out series of failures and TPWs (which is the usual way I go in this game, build, build, nurse the characters and teams, try to scrape by, then watch it all collapse like a house of cards), the game is uninstalled.

142769884.review:
What started as a wonderfully atmospheric and grimdark fantasy adventure with eldritch tones rapidly turned into a gruelling death spiral. I love the premise of the game and I really like most of the execution, it was just frustrating to end up at a dead end hours into the run and realising I'd have to start over again, but it didn't feel unfair that I ended up where I did - it was entirely the result of my choices.

The idea is that you inherit a town that borders a land infested with eldritch horrors and you need to hire heroes to clear them out and reclaim the land. The heroes plunder the depths, go crazy and get injured, you have to nurse them back to health and in the meantime send out an alternate set of heroes.

While this loop is very fun as you go on expeditions and micro manage your different teams of adventurers, the problem is that there's a limited number of times you can run a given dungeon because the dungeon itself levels up. Combine this with heroes that can perma-die and you can end up with a bunch of level 1 heroes that can't explore anything and not enough high level heroes to be of use.

If you go into the game knowing that you can play yourself into a corner lets you set your expectations accordingly. Having that sprung on me made me feel like I wasted a lot of time playing the game the 'wrong way'. I look forward to giving this another try now I'm over the salt.

142737599.review: This is a game I highly recommend. The developers have taken the rpg element to another level.

142727967.review:
"You still foolishly consider yourself an entity separate from the whole. I know better. And I. Will. Show you."

Unapologetically difficult, Darkest Dungeon makes itself clear that it is a game that is not for the faint of heart. You will lose, and you will suffer setbacks. However, through experience and carefully planning out party comps you can begin to overcome the horrors pitted against you. 

With 17 heroes to create parties from, in tandem with a choice of 7 skills per hero, there's an incredible amount of variation in party builds. Since your characters will suffer from the psychological stress of the monsters you encounter, it is common to find the characters you like are indisposed for some missions, leading you to fall back upon other heroes you normally wouldn't use. This is a great method for encouraging experimentation that the sequel fails to capture. 

The art style, music, and narrator serve to create a capturing Lovecraftian tone that caught my attention and adoration instantly. Wayne Jude does an excellent job at adding tension to uncertain encounters, and grim satisfaction at the elimination of a particularly troublesome foe with incredibly memorable quotes.

While the game may not be for everyone, it is incredibly well made, and I encourage those not afraid of failure to give it a chance. 10/10.

142657208.review:
Note: I finished my playthrough with no DLCs or mods active on the "normal" difficulty, I'll probably do other playthroughs in the future and will update this review when that happens.

For a long time, I wanted nothing to do with this game. I had heard that it is a sadistic turn based RPG that kicks your ass over and over until you are able to somehow luck your way through it or something. The megaten series came to mind, a series of extremely difficult turn based RPGs that I hate.

I was convinced by a friend to actually pick it up with the promise that the game is actually pretty fair most of the time, with the big important thing being making sure to prepare and strategize for what is up ahead. As it turns out this is correct and most people just suck really bad. Not to say that the game is easy by any means, many enemy encounters will have you sweating, and even seemingly easy enemy encounters can do enough damage to cause trouble or hit you with an effect that will disrupt your plans, but the game can be conquered if you really put your mind to it. 

A good example: One of the late game bosses humbled me after I had approached him with a little bit too much confidence and lost a unit before being forced to flee. For several days, whenever I was doing some menial task at work I started to think about the best way to counter this boss, taking all of the classes into mind. Then after over-preparing I nervously fought the boss again, to utterly destroy it because my strategy worked almost too well. THIS is what Darkest Dungeon is all about.

When you start, you won't really know the thin line between over-preparing and under-preparing, but if you really put your mind to managing your resources then you'll nail it pretty quickly and start doing pretty well. After that you can move on to figuring out which flaws are minor and which ones are major, figuring out good team compositions and formations, and finding a good balance of gold and relics to take home, and then like me you'll find yourself coming back every once and a while to push just a little bit farther.

TLDR: If you are looking for a really decent, challenging turn based RPG that is also kind of an army management game then here it is.

Great style and sound design, addictive loop but it failed to keep my interest toward the late game, dramatically.
I can accept it's a game of rolling the dice and it can go both ways, I wish the game would accept that risk as well though, the later you get the more you have to lose and yet all the mechanics of the game bend the odds worse against you, the RNG is bent further against your favor with no benefit to you and the only way to keep up is equipment RNG, when the end game makes it very likely you will lose people it puts into perspective how much fun it is grinding a character back to max and rolling for the correct equipment to even give them a chance at success. Not to mention the rest of the team being functionally worthless until you train up a replacement for their comrade, since naturally as you get into the harder levels, less optimal strategies fall off in efficacy, though I do question the decision to make almost every status effect based team near useless by late game, starts to feel a lot like railroading. Not very fun, not at all. I'd go as far as to call it monotony. Whatever their goal with this game was I don't think it was boredom, yet that's about all the late game gives me, that and a desire to play anything else.

142004699.review:
The gameplay loop is tedious, and I found I could only clear one dungeon at a time before getting too bored to continue - this equates to about 20 minutes in the early game. It just lacks that "oomph" that sucks you in and compels you to play for longer than that. What doesn't help is that, quite often, combat drags on for too long due to you and your foe missing a high proportion of your attacks.

I appreciate that bad RNG is purposeful to sell the atmosphere, and I don't mind the "losing is fun" thing it's trying to do, but it just doesn't pull this off as well as other high-difficulty games. Progression is as slow as molasses, both in the "meta", and during combat, so I felt like I was just wasting my time.

Positives: the artstyle is great, the high difficulty sells the gloomy atmosphere and lore, and the combat is punchy and satisfying (when attacks land, which they quite often don't).

Not recommended for full price, but *maybe* recommend on sale. I'll revise this if it hooks me after a few more hours, but for now it's just not doing it for me.

141619832.review:
It's hard to truly criticize the game, because it's a masterpiece. The graphics are amazing, fan mods even moreso, the music is fantastic, and the narrator is top-notch. It is one of the most iconic gothic-and-Lovecraftian horror games ever made.

That said, the game comes with some serious strings attached. The difficulty starts out tough but fair, but once you reach the titular Darkest Dungeon it becomes absurd, with even max level characters being woefully outmatched. Permadeath all but ensures that even if you make no mistakes, a single bad roll will cause a near party wipe. The fact that only 4% of players have beaten the Darkest Dungeon on normal difficulty says it all. The game really doesn't expect or ever want you to win, and I'm not sure I can fully approve of that.

If you are willing to accept you'll probably be in the 96% who never win, then by all means try your luck. Maybe if you pick Radiant you will slightly boost your chances. Maybe.

141336220.review:
Darkest dungeon advertises itself as a brutal grim dark game where things can quickly go south if things go wrong and you don't make a recovery quick enough. And it lives up to that. Your "heroes" are lost souls and desperate nobodies at the end of their luck with nowhere else to go and the game really makes you feel.

I've had my eye on this game since it first came out and it is somewhat unbelievable that I waited until 2023 to get it. I wanted to hone my turn based skills in other games before i got this. This game really rewards preparedness and I prepared. It was very satisfying to build teams with synergies and plan out my strategies. The game isn't for everyone. The games difficulty wasn't mindless dungeon crawling and is more geared towards putting meticulous purpose in every action you take.

While the game is great by itself, the dlcs are a must have, and the modding community is phenomenal. With the community content alone you could pump in 10 times more time into this game with all the content. I personally am satisfied with having only have near 100 hours into the game, but I certainly could put in more since I haven't delved deep into modding beyond a few extra classes. Red Hook making the game so easily moddable was a really smart move that has kept this game alive relevant. I would even recommend enabling mods on your first play through. This and the fact the game consistently goes on 85% discount, this game is a must have for anyone that enjoys turn based dungeon crawling fantasy combat.

Also the art style and narrator are really great. Make the game instantly recognizable and memorable.

141222274.review:
There is punishment in games to raise stakes. That is all good. If the player missteps or hesitates, they receive the punishment.

This game has RNG punishment. You can spend hours leveling up a character, and have it all go in the toilet in one encounter through no fault of your own.

You can have full torch light (which is supposed to give Monster Surpise++++) and...
- enter a Battle Room,
- not surprise the monsters,
- have all the monsters take their turns first,
- they all target one of your characters with 4 crits,
- you just wasted 3 hours and get punished through no fault of your own.

How are you supposed to "get gud" with encounters like this?

Such a shame. The game looks and sounds amazing! That's what grabbed me at first, but I completely regret putting 80+ hours into this game. I would take back the time if I could.

-- PS

Just to throw some Steam achievement stats out there:
- only 56% of players are able to beat only one boss in Darkest Dungeon.
- 50% of Dark Souls players are able to get all the way to Anor Londo (no small feat) and beat Ornstein and friggin Smough.

- 6% of players beat Darkest Dungeon on its easiest difficulty.
- 28% of players beat Dark Souls on its *only* difficulty.
