141152606.review:
I really, really love this game!
The story is decent in the way that it gives you a clear motive and objective to work towards. The lore for this game is pretty cool as well with it all being told in a H.P. Lovecraft manor. The ending may annoy people but i quite like it. There isn't really any characters except for the ancestor and i must say that his voice actor was perfect for this game. 
The Settings are really well designed and have a lot of variety to them in both aesthetics and enemy types. 
Visually, its so cool. Performance was solid throughout my playtime with there being only one crash throughout my playtime. The art direction for this game is very fitting and adds a lot of depth and mystery to the game. I really like the tiny details such as the characters not having visible eyes making the feel a lot more discomforting. 
Sound and audio are amazing with the soundtrack adding a lot of intensity and glory to the game and the audio choices for things such as using an item or hitting a critical hit just feel perfect for this game. 
In terms of gameplay, it is so infectious. Now if you aren't a fan of difficult games or games that heavily rely on rng then you might want to skip this one. Every choice in this game you make is important and the amount of micromanaging might be annoying for some but i have to say that it is really feels great to use and allows me to create the most overpowered characters possible. Everything can be customised into a comp that suits you. The one stand out thing this game offers is the stress mechanic and it can really change up the way you approach encounters and it is really well developed. Enemies vary in numerous ways and are all tough to go against.
Overall, Darkest Dungeon has quickly become one of my favourite games of all time and is definitely an experience that those who think they are great at games to try out. You will be tested!

141056133.review:
Shameless plug for in-depth essay here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6H6rciTGhWI

Darkest Dungeon is a game of meaningful challenge that is thought out in every aspect, no matter how small. The creative talent of Chris Bourassa and the coding prowess of Tyler Sigman, coupled with the great skill on display from all those at Red Hook, have turned what was once a small twist on power fantasy into a cult classic of turn-based cosmic horror. It's a true b*stard of a game, perfect for both aspiring and professional masochists, and it'll keep you reeled in from start to finish. Darkest Dungeon is a labour of love that came from a place of passion and creative liberty that is stifled in the triple A sphere of the industry. Get this game if the crack you're smoking isn't hitting right anymore.

141018043.review:
I hate that I can't give this mixed. I love this game. The atmosphere, the design, the concept, the options, it's all great.

BUT, the UI is rough, and the random generation is sooo flawed. Perfect example: it takes forever to rank up, upgrade, curate quirks, supply, and develop one character, let alone the 10, or 20, or 30 needed to win. And you can have a character INSTANTLY killed on the first room, or last room by simply: every enemy goes first, strikes your unit, causes bleed, or blight, and you get knocked into a "Deaths Door" status, and then before any unit can heal or return fire - boom perma death. This happens on all difficulties, and really doesn't matter how much you prepare. The game tells you heroes will die. That's fine. But to spend so much time, effort, planning, items, upgrades, to have a unit wiped that way nearly ruins the experience. I've uninstalled and ignored this game for months because of it, and keep swapping reviews. 

ULTIMATELY, I would recommend this game, on Radiant difficulty. But know that it's got some critical flaws. And it's not like FTL, where you can re-load, or bounce back easy. 

ALSO, the DLC's are absolute garbage. I've done entire run-through's where some units simply don't spawn as an option. So you pay for a unit, and never get to play that unit. The Farmstead is a pointless grind that wears down your units with very little reward. And the PVP one is atrocious, and had hundreds of bad reviews lowering this games status. 

I'll keep playing it, but it IS a grind, and the RNG needed a heavy overhaul years ago.

140950931.review:
Darkest Dungeon is an absolutely incredible game once you become accustomed to its mechanics. It brilliantly captures the essence of despair, illustrating the notion that when everything is horrific, nothing becomes truly dreadful. The gameplay itself imparts invaluable lessons on maintaining composure amidst adversity, guiding players towards a state of tranquility even in the darkest of moments.

The game's exceptional resource management adds another layer of depth to the experience. It feels akin to sitting at a table with a masterful dungeon master, who skillfully crafts a remarkably stressful yet captivating environment within the game. Paradoxically, this constant state of tension fosters a sense of inner calm, enabling players to deftly handle multiple challenges simultaneously.

Darkest Dungeon, with its unique blend of gameplay and atmosphere, provides a profound perspective on the human condition when faced with dire circumstances. It stands out as a masterpiece in creating a simulated yet therapeutic journey through darkness.

Highly recommended.

Tenative recommendation. Game is very grindy, and I'm no longer motivated to complete it. Really enjoyed the game at first, but the more I played the less I wanted to play it. Team management is a mess, lots of small QoL tweaks are needed, lots of micromanagement for skills and heroes when your money is stretched really thin. The game can often feel like a grind just to recoup what you spend on missions. 

The way the game is designed there's very few hero rosters that are actually worth using together, so you'll end up defaulting to a few combinations over and over. You have to level all of your heroes separately, meaning that if one group of heroes get overleveled you have to bench them while the rest of your heroes get up to their level.

You spend so much time with heroes being out of commission that your barracks HAVE to be a mess otherwise you just won't have what you need for some missions. So much grind and repeating, generic dungeons. 

Atmosphere is 910, combat is 8/10, UI and hero management is 5/10, grind factor is 100/10

140774711.review:
[h1]Many fall in the face of chaos, but not this one. Not today[/h1]

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
[b]Darkest Dungeon (DD)[/b] is a unique game, as I never played a game as punishing as this one. With the sequel recently being released, my interest was piqued to try out the first game that I happened to already own but never spent much time playing, and I'm glad that I took the opportunity to check out this gothic-themed experience.


[h1]Pros and Cons[/h1]
[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]Interesting gothic based story
[*]Fun but brutal gameplay that is very punishing
[*]Upgrades for your heroes, town, and more
[*]Beautiful 2D gothic art style
[/list]
[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]Playing this game can be a chore at times due to the needed grind
[*]There are times when you will be reliant on RNG and it might screw you over
[*]Activating some of the DLCs on your first playthrough is not recommended
[/list]

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story starts out with a man known as the [b]Ancestor[/b]; he learns of this special power that is somewhere deep in his mansion. He then uses up his family’s remaining fortune to hire people to help him dig up this mysterious power. However, it turns out that this power was something worldly and he ran from the dungeon. Only the [b]ancestry[/b] survived and he wrote a letter to the next heir of the family, to fix the mistake he made. After he sealed the letter and before the angry mob of villagers that were mad for what he did could get him, the [b]Ancestor[/b] had ended his life.

The story for [b]Darkest Dungeon[/b] is not fully told to you directly, rather, it’s told to you at different points in the game, mainly before you do boss missions. It’s interesting at the very least and I like the gothic [b]Cthulhu mythos[/b] theme it has going for it. Although [b]DD[/b] takes inspiration from the [b]Lovecraftian[/b] universe, there are also different inspirations that are included as well. The heroes you hire also have back stories to them as well.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The gameplay for [b]Darkest Dungeon[/b] is fun but also very challenging and at the same time, it can be very difficult to grasp. There are many mechanics that you yourself have to try and get used to. You will be able to hire different heroes that each have different abilities for them to use. Each of them also may have a different mechanic that corresponds to them, however, they all do share the stress feature. Stress in the game is determined by what the hero goes through in a given situation. When stress reaches 100, that hero will have a certain negative Affliction inflicted on them, like them being fearful, paranoid, etc. 

However, there is a chance that some heroes will be given a virtue when they reach 100 stress, they get increased stats and will randomly heal themselves. So, while most heroes get afflictions and break, others will use their stressful moments as something to encourage themselves. If a hero gets to 200 stress, they will lose the virtue and go back to zero stress, while those with afflictions suffer a heart attack.

During combat, your heroes can do certain attacks or abilities to buff/debuff allies or enemies. Each hero has a certain amount of health and it does vary, when their health runs out they will be put under a [b]Death’s Door[/b] status. When they are in this state, they will suffer state penalties and they have to go through a test to see if they will survive the next attack. I should note that if your hero is at 1 health and the enemies attack them with a move that does a lot of damage, they will tank the entire attack except the one damage. The only way for a hero to die is by failing the [b]Death’s Door[/b] test.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2995283070
If a hero suffers a heart attack while at [b]Death’s Door[/b], they will be killed immediately, when a hero dies, they are lost for good and will also lose the equipped charms they have. You can recover them if you lose a hero in battle but if it’s outside of one, they are gone completely. So pray that your best heroes survive the attacks and that their stress does not get too high.

There are ways to relieve stress, like taking out enemies or using a camping ability at a campsite. If your heroes survive the mission, you sent them on, you can send them to a few stress-reducing activities like making them meditate, drink at the bar, gamble, pray, etc. There are also times when a hero will get a disease, so you must take them to the [b]Sanitarium[/b] for them to get cured. A hero can get a max of three diseases, if they happen to get another one, it will just replace one of the current diseases they have. Last I checked diseases don’t necessarily work like that but who knows, I am not a medical expert.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2995282569
I should at least give a little tip/warning that if any hero happens to get stunned, for them to recover it will take that hero's turn. Enemies get the same treatment as well. In other words, [b]Red Hook Studios[/b] took some inspiration from the original [b]Persona 3[/b] game and wanted to bring back memories.

Certain moves will also only be available for you to use if that hero is in a certain spot in the party. If they happened to get moved or pushed back, they will be unable to use certain attacks or support abilities. It’s understandable for some attacks but for others it’s absolutely stupid - like, the [b]Vestal[/b] can’t use her [b]Divine Grace[/b] or [b]Divine Comfort[/b] abilities, which heal party members, if she is in the front. I understand that she is a support hero but it’s still pretty dumb that she can’t use those abilities if she happens to be pushed into the front.

Now as much as [b]DD[/b] is fun, there are a few issues with the game that don’t hinder the experience but can be a turn-off for some people. Playing [b]DD[/b] can be a chore sometimes, you will have to do a lot of grinding depending on the difficulty that you choose. This is normal for an [b]RPG[/b] like this game but it can get very repetitive for some people. To add to the fact is that the game also relies on RNG for almost everything that happens in it. Trust me, when your hero misses an attack you will feel pain.

Some of the DLCs in the game are also not recommended to be activated on your very first playthrough. Ones like the [b]Butcher’s Circus[/b] (which is online PvP) or the [b]Musketeer[/b] are fine because they just add features that don’t hinder the experience for the player. However, DLCs like the [b]Crimson Court[/b] add stuff like more grind, a very annoying status debuff, and is just punishing to new players. Buy the DLC on your first playthrough if you just want an even more painful experience.

[h1]Graphics and Performance[/h1]
The art style for [b]DD[/b] is absolutely beautiful, I love the gothic-based art style that the game has going for it, and is very detailed. I experienced no issues while I was playing the game.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2995283203
I tested the game on an NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1060 3GB, AMD Ryzen 5 1500X Quad-Core Processor 3.50, and 16 GB of RAM. 

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
There is a lot that I haven’t talked about with [b]Darkest Dungeon[/b] as there are numerous things to uncover from the game. If you are someone who wants to play a very punishing game, then this is the right one for you and you will get your money’s worth because a playthrough could go up to at least 50+ hours.

140650262.review:
I played this game maybe two years ago with Xbox Gamepass, but I recently came back to it after I saw it on Steam for a huge discount sale. Originally, I played it and after a couple hours, I went "Oh, this game is just hard for the sake of being hard" and didn't touch it after.

After starting a new save today, I'm enjoying it more and more. Once you understand the mechanics and some strategies for it, Darkest Dungeon is up there with Morrowind. Most people that try games with in-depth mechanics and punishment for bad decisions just tend to say the game is unfair and uninstall it after they refused to learn or play by the game's rules. This game gave me that feeling of "eh, just one more dungeon" after every completed quest. This game rewards you for being good at it. It makes you feel smart once you understand the basics and play under the constraints (rules) that the game explicitly warns you about every time you boot it up. It's nothing but honest to a fault.

The music, art style, voice acting, and tone of the game are good. The combat loop can be addictive and it never makes you feel comfortable with it. The moment you get cocky, the game slaps you across the face and staunchly reminds you to not be too confident simply because you think you've mastered it. Most of the time when your party dies it's because it's usually your fault. Some people don't like that and that's fine. Some people that play games want to turn their brain off and want a power fantasy. Darkest Dungeon doesn't give you that luxury and it never feels cheap about it.

It's a pretty neat game.

140593503.review: Darkest Dungeon is very unique with its brutal lovecraftian horror take on dungeon crawling and the resulting trauma that the characters can endure assuming they don't die in the process. Despite having a pretty lackluster tutorial, once you start to understand the meat of the game with party composition, prepping, and all the optimal rng picks to make as you fight through the turn based battles, it can be a pretty engaging loop. It takes a different mindset than most games as you are bound to simply get wiped out at different points, often due entirely to bad luck, but it seems as though the game was designed around it. My only real gripes with the game are that too often it expects you to learn through trial and error on large scales, resulting in you unknowingly being party wiped at any given moment. It also starts to feel a bit tedious having only made it 20 hours in, and I think the novelty of the party mixing and matching is less effective once you reach mid game. In general I think the game is great but I'll probably never finish it as it seems to get grindy and I have better things to spend my time on. But especially on sale, I'd recommend most people at least give it a try for themselves.

140462454.review:
Wow! Nearly 200 hours! You must really like Darkest Dungeon, right?

Wrong. Darkest dungeon is a roguelite with a fantastic start, and a woeful endgame. A wonderful idea twisted into a horrible, bloated mess - which I suppose is fitting given the theme.

Standard opening: Who the hell am I? I'm the guy who;

-Likes a good indie RPG.
-Likes a new mechanic
-Is a working adult with a full-time job
-Is not a 100% completionist
-Likes "Lovecraftian" a little more than "Lovecraft"
-But okay, 'Mountains of Madness' wasn't bad

Darkest Dungeon is a turn-based, dungeon crawl roguelike, set in a Lovecraftian world. You are tasked with recruiting various classes of hero into your roster, sending them out to fight the darkness. Over the course of the playthrough you will likely see many heroes fall, but with (an awful lot of) determination you will see you town and heroes grow, and push against the darkness.

Darkest Dungeon is incredibly well-stylised, and works its limited graphics better than almost any game I have seen. The artwork itself is extremely limited and the animation barely existent but time has been taken to make the transitions and feel right. This is complemented by an iconic narrator whose tone and extent of contributions meant that I never grew tired of listening to them.

Such is the commitment to the Lovecraftian concept, that your party members have not only a health meter but a sanity meter. In practice this means little more than juggling two health bars, but thematically it works well. Darkest dungeon is unusual in that its bullshit-o-meter runs absolutely off the scale - one enemy crit cascade added fifteen hours to my playthrough. However it all seems to tie in to the theme well.

Darkest Dungeon is enjoyable, challenging, well-written and generally well-presented indie RPG. I have no doubt whatsoever that you will enjoy it.

The start of it, at least.

See, Darkest Dungeon expresses some quite astonishing delusions of grandeur about its own lifespan. This is a game that you can happily sink 30 hours into, whose "abridged" campaign will take closer to 80, and whose unabridged campaign is probably closer to 150. It has no business being as long as it is. The four areas have two bosses each. For no reason other than length you fight these bosses three times each. And you grind and grind and grind.

When eventually the bosses are done, the end-game doubles down on the pain with the sort of level design they should teach out of you on day 1 of design school. Overly long dungeons that, should a character die (at which point your run is to all intents and purposes over) you must kill another character to retreat. Two enemies critted my full-health Vestal back-to-back, and she died from the resulting bleed. I retreated and lost my tank. Lacking another appropriate healer and tank (because characters can only take end-game dungeons once?!) I had to grind up from level 2 a new party. WHY?!

I have finally completed Darkest Dungeon and now can put it to bed. An exercise in how to outstay your welcome. Recommended with caution.

140426988.review:
Nos volvemos a sumergir en la mazmorra más oscura, esta vez con la versión final del juego, para descubrir hasta dónde ha sido capaz Red Hook Studios de llevar su título de rol. Y no hay duda de que lo ha conseguido excavando hondo, hasta lo más profundo del género.

Puede que Darkest Dungeon no sea para todo el mundo, pero eso es exactamente lo que hace que si disfrutas de un juego con personalidad, lo hagas por partida doble. Pero es que este pequeño gran juego de rol y estrategia por turnos no tiene compasión por los más impacientes. Desde el primer momento te pide una concentración extrema mientras sus tutoriales te explican lo básico y el resto ya lo aprenderás por el camino.

El argumento es aquí menor protagonista, pero lo poco que se nos cuenta para arrancar la aventura es suficiente: un familiar nos escribe una carta donde nos revela que somos el único heredero de unas tierras y la mansión familiar que en una ocasión brillaron con esplendor, pero que ahora están asoladas por un antiguo mal que ha despertado al intentar excavar en las ruinas sobre las que se construyó el gran caserón. Será nuestro deber entonces limpiar sus mazmorras y restablecer el buen nombre de nuestra casa.

Para ello, cuatro héroes se encargarán de recorrer distintas zonas como laberintos, bosques y poblados malditos enfrentándose a criaturas de pesadilla. Todo en una distribución bastante clásica de juego de rol por turnos, en los que podremos realizar todo tipo de ataques o hacer uso de habilidades únicas de cada clase. Y si algo tiene Darkest Dungeon, es una gran cantidad de clases entre las que elegir, que fomenta la rejugabilidad del título y hace que cada combate se tenga que afrontar de distinta forma.
verdadera mecánica del juego es en su sistema de estrés y cordura y en la necesidad de mantener a un buen número de héroes en buen estado mental. Estas criaturas de pesadilla están basadas en el horror cósmico de Lovecraft, y como muchos juegos antes que él, siempre que se aborda este tipo de terror, se juega con la cordura y locura de nuestros personajes. A medida que vamos avanzando por las mazmorras irán acumulando estrés y si llega a un límite su determinación se pondrá a prueba, lo que dará lugar a sacar lo mejor o lo peor de sí mismos. Pero si alcanza el límite será prácticamente como haberlos perdido en combate.

Este sistema lo envuelve todo, porque mientras que vamos aliviando a nuestros personajes en el pueblo, tendrán que ser sustituidos por otros. Y esto significa que tendremos que utilizar a todo nuestro grupo frecuentemente si no queremos que los reservas se queden con poco nivel. Porque aquí, una muerte es irrecuperable y si tus otros personajes no están a la altura, no podrás continuar con la aventura.

Así que, mientras que unos entran en las mazmorras más oscuras, otros tendrán que descansar y relajarse en el pueblo. Según su condición, algunos preferirán la Taberna, mientras que otros querrán rezar a entidades superiores en la Abadía. Todo ello hará que disminuya el estrés y estén listos para combatir. Pero a lo largo de su carrera también irán desarrollando otro tipo de filias y fobias que habrá que curar en el Sanatorio, pues si se acumulan demasiadas podrán llegar a ser demasiado imprevisibles e incontrolables.
Todo ello aparte de ir mejorando sus habilidades en el Gremio, para lograr que los ataques sean más poderosos o las curaciones más eficientes, y mejorar el equipo en la herrería o las dotes de liderazgo para las acampadas. Demasiadas gestiones para el poco dinero del que disponemos en cada incursión, pues todo en Darkest Dungeon es tremendamente caro. Hay otra moneda de cambio: los bustos, emblemas, escrituras y cuadros que encontramos en las mazmorras nos ayudarán a mejorar cada establecimiento y lograr que los precios bajen un porcentaje.
Y así, van pasando las semanas en el juego, las mazmorras se van haciendo más difíciles y tendremos que ir derrotando a los jefazos que nos esperan al final de cada una de ellas; seguir subiendo de nivel, seguir cuidando de nuestros héroes mientras contratamos nuevos en la Diligencia. Es por ello que quizá el mayor problema que hemos tenido con Darkest Dungeon es que se puede volver algo rutinario y acusa esa repetición de actividades al tener que ir con paciencia, poco a poco, donde las novedades van siendo cada vez más escasas. Es cierto que su mecánica principal es tan atractiva que te mantiene enganchado al teclado y ratón durante mucho tiempo, pero se echan de menos establecimientos y habilidades avanzadas que nos hagan replantearnos de nuevo toda la aventura, ya que mucho de su contenido se desbloquea en los primeros compases del juego
Donde no hay pega alguna es en sus decisiones de diseño. Red Hook ha sido muy inteligente al crear un sistema de exploración 2D que le da personalidad propia con unos dibujos de gran calidad y, sobre todo, una gran contundencia en las batallas, en las que se siente cada golpe propinado y cada cuchillo o hechizo lanzado. A esta contundencia ayuda mucho el sonido, visceral y buen mezclado, junto a una voz del narrador atronadora y unos monólogos fenomenalmente escritos y que ambientan a la perfección. El juego además cuenta con traducción a nuestro idioma, algo que se había echado de menos en los primeros compases del título como Early Access.

140357113.review:
Overrated. 
Not difficult due to decision making or strategy, but from the most miserly petty economy of any game in history.

First you spend all your money on supplies for a dungeon, then if you leave the dungeon you lose those supplies and have to buy them again when you go back out. WHY? Why wouldn't I keep my supplies that I bought with my hard earned money, especially with such a miserly economy? It's ridiculous and feels like it just artificially makes the game harder and not in a good way.

To make the cheap economy worse, you can go 80% through a dungeon and still not have picked up enough 'loot' to justify the equipment you bought to make the dungeon run. So leaving before the end leaves you screwed. Do that a few times and you're so broke you have to start a new game. Then again continue with such damaged characters and someone or more will probably die. Not a good design IMO.

Next you are always dealing with stress. And one enemy puts 17 stress on ALL your characters in one hit, but then your only recourse is a skill that ONE of your guys has that takes a full turn, but only cures A COUPLE of points of fear on ONE person. WOW. GEE, thanks for NOTHING. IF they survive the dungeon run, back at town stress persists and you have to pay a LOT of money for LITTLE stress relief. Again, stupidly cheap, intentionally frustrating economy.

Also you can't get attached to your characters because chintzy economy and worthless 'healing' mentioned above and practically forcing you to complete dungeons when people are badly injured and stressed.

Also adding to above, some of your characters just get focused like crazy no matter what position they're in or what aggro taking abilities you have on other characters. They all just INSIST on taking that one character out. Again, don't get attached to any characters.

And by the way, who the heck are YOU? 

You are supposed to be the owner of the land this desecrated castle is upon, but then you don't actually appear in the game as a character. Bizarre. Of course they had to go with such a weird design decision as YOU would just die anyway like everyone else in your broke impoverished healing-free party and the story couldn't progress. This decision ruins immersion and makes you as attached to the story as you are to the characters you pick, which is to say not at all.

Frustrating and disappointing. 
Artificially 'hard' to impress elitists / masochists, all for all the wrong reasons.
Sorry but I suspect the majority thumbs this up, then plays a couple more hours then NEVER touches it again.
Completion rate is probably 1% and that is NOT a thumbs up game IMO.

140315566.review:
This game is intent on wasting your time, and I do get it. It slaps you over the face with a through line that you're trading meat for knowledge and progress. They give you so many cute little options to do things like change your units’ appearance name to ask you to care about them and it is a trick to ask you to waste your time. The core gameplay of dungeon delving is almost as horrifying in that every animation and move between rooms is excruciatingly slow. That means that not only is your time customizing the characters at stake, but the entire cumulative time of dungeons cleared and stress reduced is what you're risking when a character dies. This was genuinely intolerable for me when I first approached this game and I put it aside for later, presumably when I was better at video games.

Actual years passed, and I saw Black Reliquary release. It looked cool, so I poked around and saw it was a mod pack which was much more difficult than the base game, so if I wanted to engage with that fully, I might as well try this game. Looking through the mods of this game is very difficult because most of the collections arrange by users have completely unhelpful (predominately pornographic) imagery as thumbnails. Some of the quality-of-life mods are in all the most popular collections, and they are additionally bundled with cosmetic mods which may or may not be up to personal taste. 

As an aside, it can be considered unfortunate that the only consistent reskins of the game's assets are nsfw. I suspect this is because all the work it takes to bring a complete 'character' to life, which includes specialized animation knowledge, demands more than a hobbyist engagement. While there is a way to fund indie projects where it is free for everyone once it is completed, that crowdfunding model structurally favors porn, to be blunt. That fact is clear, but the why is well beyond the scope of this review. Know simply that the mods for making characters and npcs look different which are sfw are few and far between and are likely to have disparate and incompatible art directions.

What I did personally was download all the mods that steam marked my friends as having also subscribed to. I got all of the quality-of-life mods necessary to make most of the game's problems far more bearable, and it clicked for me. The game is a very tidy rpg if only it wasn't "pretentious" in hammering in the point of how brutal and high stakes it is precisely by wasting so much of your time. That said, my mod selection contained beastiality imagery, so I would strongly advise having more discretion than I did. 

After completing the first quest of the Darkest Dungeon, the game begins employing graphical tricks I would merely describe as 'cute' to try and emphasize a turn for horror. I won't be specific about what happens but suffice it to say I got tired of it over the course of two hours. I've had mostly negative things to say about the game and honestly, I probably should disown the game as a grindy piece of garbage which is intent on wasting your time, but that mod support really can salvage it. Mileage varies, but an assortment of "speed increase" and "automatic save" mods can go a long way in making the game accessible and breezy experience. If you have nostalgia for a difficulty implementation which resembles 'getting punched in the nads really hard and being told to go back and doing the entire section over again, perhaps with even less resources than before', the base experience and difficulty options remain.

140235212.review:
This is a strategy game with tons of replay value. There are rooms that you move through each with a myriad of traps, monsters, or just nothing. You balance a party of four from a larger roster of fighters that you accrue. As with RPGs - weapons, potions, armor, position, skill, class all play integral roles in a careful balance between squad success or squad wipe.

If a game draws me in consistently on first play through then it gets a favored position in my library.

EDIT: However, upon regular play through, the game is slanted towards the player always on the edge of a major threat. It feels forced and manufactured to create a tension heavy playing experience. To me, this is inauthentic as a mechanic because it becomes a game of finding the "goldilocks" zone rather than being properly prepared for each dungeon encounter. In fact, you might be better off being less prepared because then the game might artificially balance it towards your favor. 

On my last playthrough I tried to intentionally wipe my party and that was harder than actually putting in an effort the time before that trying to keep them alive. That's when I knew something was seriously amiss with the balancing. 

I had high hopes that this was a true strategic experience and it falls way short of anything resembling strategy that could be impactful towards your playstyle. This is a game of chance. If I want to play a game of chance, I'll go play a card game. I think this is my first negative review.

140023110.review:
EDIT: So after a couple weeks time away from the game after my biggest setback, I decided to come back to the game with the mindset of "The failure isn't falling down, but staying down", and ended up finally beating it after so many years of attempts.
I will keep my original review listed below, as it does highlight good reasons as to why this game might not be everyone's cup of tea. [u]But my own thoughts on the game have changed,[/u] I do still enjoy it despite it's frustrations - namely overcoming them. If you enjoy a ruthless challenge and seek to triumph in the face of adversity, then I would absolutely recommend the game.

Original review:
The game is fun, for the most part. But by the end-game a single mistake can cost you hours of work trying to make heroes resolve rank 6, which isn't helped by how evasive and dangerous enemies get in champion levels.
It's so unbelievably frustrating to, for example; [i]need[/i] a hero with the guard ability for the 2nd Darkest Dungeon, but every hero who reached high enough level to enter that location getting killed due to negligence and/or unlucky RNG, forcing you to re-train another one from scratch (even with all the stagecoach upgrades, the chances of specifically getting a rank 3 guard hero are slim, and still requires a ton of money and work to make them viable for DD).

I've had the game since early access - back when it was a viable strategy to have four heroes with the abusive affliction and go on pure dark runs, as heart attacks didn't exist back then - but was never able to beat it. And my latest playthrough to cross that off my bucket list has been plagued by scenarios like those described above, routinely sending hours of work down the drain.

The game is undeniably good - great storytelling, music and nail-biting difficulty. But if you're like me, there's only so much frustration that you can take before your enjoyment is completely soured. (It wasn't helped by the fact that I accidentally loaded a save before my mods had been prepared, which outright deleted half my roster of modded heroes. That's my own fault, I'll concede, but its still hurts since there's no way to go back to an older save to fix that mistake).

TL;DR: The game is good, but simply not for me. Something something skill issues.

139962665.review:
This game is...wow, just wow. Unbelievable tension, I don't think any game has kept me so tense in my entire life.

What is Darkest Dungeon exactly, and what makes the game sucj a rollercoaster of stress and satisfaction?

Darkest Dungeon is a lovecraftian turn-based RPG with beautiful (or frightening) hand drawn lovecraftian-inspired character, enemy and environment designs. And does the game inspire fear with more elements than just its graphics...the bleakness that surrounds the game is directly translated into tough gameplay, intrincated mechanics and tough enemies.

Darkest Dungeon's most notable feature is the stress meter, which is a separate bar just above your health bar which will cause a trigger when it reaches its mid-point, with impacting consequences. Would the stress meter be full, your character could very well suffer a heart attack. It's just awesome, specailly in a game where you can continuously recruit new ¿heroes? but yet has a nasty permadeath mechanic.

This doesn't mean the game doesn't give you tools to go through its many dungeons: there are roughly over a dozen different classes to choose from and many combinations to try. Trial and error is vital in this game since it follows its own rules and mechanics, and experimenting with different party combinations made my day. Mercenaries can be upgraded when leveled-up and they can learn new abilites. Knowing who t chosse, or which abilities to pich depending on the different zones in the game, is crucial.

And whil the learning curve is steep at the beginning, with enough effort you can more or less master the game and its mechanics, competently entering dungeons with a high chances of success. But all it takes is one unlucky fight for things to get ugly...enemies will not want to make this wasy for you, specially when encountering new ones, and while the variety is just okay, some enemy party combinations have the potential to trash your party depending on its composition and placement. Big shout to the area bossess which are all not only way tougher than regular enemies, but also possess their own, and very flavorful gimmicks which you will have to learn and master...or face death. And don't get me started with the final zone of the game...you thought you had it all under control but there's a good difficulty spike there (and also a highly impacting design decision that will irritate some...and make others clap in respect to the flaour).

This game is not only challenging but also lenghty enough, at about 60hours to reach full completion.

For its current price tag, I would totally give it a try, and would recommend people to see if the kind of tense, pseudo-masochistic fun that Darkest Dungeon provides its their kind of spice. For me it's a 9,5/10 masterpiece.

139775541.review:
This reminds me of the Dungeon Crawl Classics game I played in High School. DCC is an rpg where each player starts out with four characters, who all go through a level-0 adventure, called a Funnel. The game is extremely lethal and regularly unfair, and any character who survives that first excursion levels up and gets the privilege of being a main character. Darkest Dungeon is that experience in video-game form, you watch a herd of characters slowly grow and suffer over a protracted period, and it's really something special. The mechanics are frequently frustrating, but it feels deliberate. If the idea of having a bad time on purpose turns you off, you should probably stay miles away from DD. If you're a fan of pokemon nuzlockes, you're probably going to love this one. 
If I have to levy any real criticisms, runs go on a bit too long. The game's very punishing, but it's bad at telling you when you've lost. I don't know if I've ever actually scrubbed out of a DD run, but I've conceded a lot of them. Also, the number of characters you need to juggle over the course of a run makes it very easy to lose track of emergent narratives.

139698235.review:
[h1]It's hard, harsh and unforgiving.[/h1]

Most fantasy stories portray adventuring as an easy, even glamorous profession. These heroic badasses frequently swagger into labryinths, smash all the bad guys, steal all the loot, and when necessary, resurrect themselves with reckless abandon. But usually, these heroes are human beings. Humans can become frightened, they can have doubts, they can lose their minds and even betray their allies when their survival is threatened. They can succumb to post-traumatic stress after particularly harrowing experiences. These traits are at odds with the daring depictions of heroic characters, and so they are glossed over or sugarcoated. In Darkest Dungeon, they are an integral part of the game.

Before the events of the narrative, the player character's long-lost relative contacts them via letter, explaining that he has done something horribly wrong and paid for it dearly. He was a bored, jaded nobleman, and one day decided to investigate the rumors of an interdimensional portal underneath his castle. The rumors were true, and he unleashed a grotesque, terrifying horde of creatures on the surrounding countryside. The horrors were enough to drive him mad, and after summoning his estranged relative, he commits suicide.

Upon arrival in the hamlet beneath the hills of the haunted family mansion, I was given a small group of adventurers and a bleak message from the game itself, informing me that bad things were going to happen. I collected my eager, fresh band of heroes and an assortment of provisions (no Xanax, unfortunately), and then descended into the darkness for glory and treasure. Well, that’s what I hoped to find - more often I found derangement and despair. Every mission in Darkest Dungeon is randomly generated, with new rooms and hallways filled with curios, wealth, traps, and monsters. Whenever I reached a chest, corpse, or bookshelf to investigate, random effects would occur depending on my party’s statistics and provisions. Sometimes we were awarded some gold, or a trap would spring and inflict a party member with a terrible disease. Most of these encounters are avoidable, but the fights are not.

Instead of the tiles found in earlier roguelikes, Darkest Dungeon uses a two-dimensional presentation. During fights, my party of four was arranged to the left of the enemy party of 1-4, and opportunities are determined by the placement of a character within the formation. My arbalest-bearer, for instance, is better towards the back of the party, where she has enough room to shoot her crossbow. The healers like to be in the middle, and the paladins and shieldbearers belong up front. Party abilities can synergize with each other for tactical advantages - the jester can shuffle the party around and open up combo opportunities, while the bounty hunter can "mark" targets for big bonuses from other members. Of course, enemies can also do these things, and they have an AI capable of taking every possible advantage.

It’s not just the health of my heroes that I’m concerned with. Some enemies, as well as the conditions of the dungeon, can inflict stress damage. Stress is a secondary form of damage that, if accumulated too quickly, will generate quirks, neurotic tendencies, and downright psychosis. My heroes would crack when the burden got too high and lose their nerve, suffering from masochism, selfishness, or other maladies, which can lead to lost turns and increased stress on their allies. One of my first paladins, Reynauld, is a degenerate kleptomaniac, prone to stealing treasure in the field and keeping it for himself. One of my healers has an obsession with sainthood and takes every opportunity to martyr herself. My favorite highwayman suffers from alcoholism, and so on and so forth. These afflictions, as well as the myriad diseases that can be contracted in these filthy environments, can all be cured at the local sanitarium - for a price. Stress can be reduced via religious devotion and nighttime revelry, but all of this is only possible for heroes who are actually able to survive the expedition, which is a tall order. Heroes who die are permanently lost, but green recruits arrive weekly in the village. Little did they know they would become just another resource to me, as expendable as the torches and rations that accompanied them on their forays.

Darkest Dungeon is a mixture of stylish comic-like characters and a dark, gothic environment. The fingerprints of Lovecraft and Poe can be seen everywhere, from the tentacled monsters of the cove to the iron bars of the asylum. The effects match the theme perfectly - during battles, fighters cut into the foreground when they attack, and their model switches to a horrified grimace when something bad happens, like losing their mind. Movement animations are simple, but the character models are very detailed in their 2D way.

The music was composed by Canadian musician Stuart Chatwood, who also worked on 'Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time'. It is heavy on the strings and Victorian flavor, and like the gameplay, is deep, dark, and depressing. The narrator (whose character is the dead former proprietor of the castle) is the only voice besides enemy barks, and his pained, guttural delivery is excellent.

It's thick roguelike influences means that Darkest Dungeon is the kind of game that thrives when it is played over and over. Every dungeon is procedurally generated, every chest has a chance at strange fortune, and every new character offers a different set of abilities. Even when times are tough (and they will be tough, I assure you) upgrades can be made to the village facilities that slowly improve the heroes’ quality of life and chance at survival. In turn, the dungeons also get more challenging.

Darkest Dungeon is the rare game that gets my heart pumping while playing, not because it’s scary (even though it is a little scary), but because the stakes are so high. One battle can make the difference between waltzing out flush with loot, and returning home defeated, with the party dead or completely insane. It will punish your mistakes and it will even punish your good fortune, on the rare occasion it happens. Despite all of this, or perhaps because of it, I cannot seem to stop playing Darkest Dungeon.

139631437.review:
TL;DR: Game will induce masochism through RNG rigged against the player and either sadistic game design, or severe oversight. Economy/Base-Building Side is very satisfying.

A game to recommend to someone for all of the wrong reasons.

This game should not be fun. It just shouldn't be.

You get punished for doing a good thing, you get punished for doing a bad thing, and occasionally, randomly, you get fucked because the game decided it's Fuck-O'Clock in the morning and you look ripe for the pickin'.

Surprising an enemy sounds like a good idea, right? Well, not in this game. Because surprising an enemy doesn't net you an extra turn, rather just you all go first. So, if you can't kill all of them in one turn, the enemy now gets 2, 3, or 4 turns to fuck up your guys without any recourse.

And let's not forget that the RNG is incredibly biased, or at the very least feels biased, towards the enemy. They will consistently crit and land low-chance hits while they dodge every attack aimed back at them. This compounds into the problem of surprising enemies actually not being a good thing, because enemies will line their ducks up, then proceed to double-crit a party member, promptly kill them, and all because you managed to surprise them, which is a random event in this game.

Make no mistake, this game is very fun and satisfying when it wants to be. Landing hefty blows in the 30s and 40s of damage is incredibly satisfying when you've built a party or character for that purpose. But my god, this game is an even tug-of-war game at its fairest, and a suicide mission at its worst.

As far as the economy sides of things goes, collecting treasure and upgrading buildings and managing your party through the Hamlet, it actually feels fairly balanced. Everything is a decision, there is no willy-nilly buying upgrades. The upgrades feel well-priced, allowing you to usually upgrade one or two party members per run, with some money spent towards recuperation. The Trinkets, the Busts, Portraits, Deeds, and Crests, work very well as resources, requiring you to hold onto them as treasures in the place of gold or other valuable items, or adventuring supplies, like torches, food, or curatives, forcing you to prioritize expanding your town or resting, recuperating, and fortifying your adventurers. 

The Trinkets as a system and as part of the Hamlet, are well-designed and play into the games focus on careful decision-making, even if that focus is shot in the knees by some odd design choices and really wack RNG.

139607956.review:
worth the money, to say the very least.

this game has a huge rep for being super difficult-- and you will encounter a lot more situations in this game that you simply can't get out of; you *will* lose sometimes no matter how strong your gamer genes-- but it isn't nearly as bad as the community would have you believe. the vast majority of situations can be easily weathered by preparing and not panicking (as with all turn-based games, you have unlimited time to think through your moves). for the sake of metaphor-- and these *are* Sun Tzu numbers here-- let's say a normal rougelike or rougelite (or really any game) will have 1% of situations you face require a high degree of luck and not be made close-to-trivial by preparation, experience, and thinking; in Darkest Dungeon, that number is something like 10% or 15%. everytime you open the game, it warns you of this fact, and you really should have an idea of if that's for you well within the steam refund window.

this game would probably still be worth its price if it was just a walking simulator where you got to hear the Ancestor (DD's acclaimed narrator) talk about trivial things. every piece of non-gameplay content (voicelines, character barks, lore, tooltips, art, etc.) is exceptional. charming characters, striking and memorable art, and the best narration I've yet heard in a game. also, as a side note, the majority of vocabulary used by the Ancestor not still in use today is from Tudor-era England (look up 'gong farmer'.)

one caveat, though certainly not game-changing, is that the final set of three missions (the titular 'Darkest Dungeon') aren't difficult in the same way as the rest of the game. everything beforehand, as talked about before, is challenging and brutal, requiring a much higher degree of thought at all from the player than most single-player games, but still having recourse for players willing to step up, cut their losses when needed, and actually put resources to use (potion hoarding-esque behavior will get you killed in this game). the final mission, however, is not this. it is what people *think* the entire game is. unforgiving, unfair, unfun-- 'bullshit' is how most would put it. I completed the first of three missions after losing 2 or 3 entire high-level parties (which, believe it or not, are incredibly tedious to replace-- note I say tedious, not difficult); I tried the second of three several times, losing as many if not more heroes. thematically the DD is amazing, but it just unravels the fun of the game up to it. so I considered that save done. really, it's that easy. you can do literally everything else in the game without so much as looking at the final quest, so if you end up feeling the same you can just not do it. I understand that's frustrating for some, so know before you buy that the very end is not the same as the rest.

despite that criticism, my only major critique of the game, I still highly recommend this title. I got this game on sale for 5$, but it's definitely worth the full 25$. I put nearly 100 hours into this game, with something like 90 of them being pre-Darkest Dungeon on my first save, and something like 5 being with the final missions. overall that's great value even at full price without considering just how excellent nearly every aspect of the game is. I cannot understate how intriguing, engrossing, and well-polished this title is. 

as another side note: in my 100 hours I did not encounter a single bug

139513686.review:
[h1] "Remind Yourself That Overconfidence Is A Slow And Insidious Killer." [/h1]
Tried the game 3 years ago and gave up and ended up completing the main story on build 25721 a couple days ago with the large majority of the game being a great first experience into the roguelike genre.

[h2] Story [/h2]
Storywise this game is average, while it is explained why you are in the town and what your goal is through the narrator and memoirs, it honestly felt forgettable; nothing really stuck to me. I could not figure out what caused the black magic in the first place or the change in intro towards boss dungeons without watching a video after I completed the game. Then again you are not really playing this game for the story, but for the roguelike dungeon experience. Voice acting, music and sounds are top-notch especially during lower torch levels. It actually made me feel anxious about progressing.

[h2] Graphics/Level-Design/World [/h2]
Visually the art style fits the game and is unique, everything from the abilities, character design and the dungeon itself looked great. Each of the zones looked unique and you could tell what zone you are in without a name just from enemies and the environment. The only design direction I did not like was how some characters like the Hellion have a large head proportional to her body, kind of making her look like a Chibi. Enemy wise, they matched their zone with their resistances being relevant such as more blight resistance in the warrens. The only issue I have with the enemies is how their stats are presented, I understand this is roguelike but nowhere in the game glossary or hover is it explained the effect of value of resistances. For instance I have been able to stun an enemy with 50 stun resistance but in the 60+ hours I’ve played I have not stunned 100, 200 or 300 enemies yet for blight I have managed to get it to proc enemies with up to 150+. It’s the same for acc on enemies. Why do I need to use the wiki to find out a swine ability hit rate is 82.5, it should just show me that in game. It is actually convoluted how none of this is explained in game.

[h2]Bugs [/h2]
Performance wise the game runs great, it is not an inherently demanding game with the art style. So you should not have any issues running this game. Bug wise I did encounter stat bugs such as acc showing 0 when it should be showing a significantly high number. It does update correctly after an action but it's too late at that point. Aside from that I have not experienced any bugs.

[h2]Conclusion [/h2]
If you want to try out a roguelike for the first time this game is a great entry into the genre, the game does a great job at encouraging persistence when your hero dies. But I do think as a new player a lot of things can be better explained and presented in-game. I recommend getting this game especially if it's on discount.
